It has a selection box to display with or with out answers, so a teacher could print the assessment out and give the assessment in class and could also print out an answer key. It also has some nice js magic on it so that you can adjust the font size in the print out as well.

column1: [SAK-7996] Offer option of displaying user's photo where usernames are typically displayed
column6:
There are a variety of tools that display usernames in lists or when viewing single items. It should be possible to display photos, along with the usernames. This can help remind folks of who the person is, particularly for instructors who haven't put names to faces yet early in the term; and, it also provides a nice visual short-hand throught the semester or life-time of the project, if you're better at remembering who a person is by their face rather than by their name

Such functionality, however, probably needs to be optional, as some campus will need to disable it site-wide for privacy reasons, some implmentations may support individual user's decisions to share a photo or not, some project sites might want to enable/disable this on a site-wide basis, etc.

User Case:

  • Instructor wants to see photo id of student when grading that student's assignment or assessment.
  • Instructor wants to print out a photo roster of their course to take with them to class to help remind them of who is who
  • Project site participants want to see photos of who created or last modified a Resource in the list, rather than usernames.
  • Photos can be placed next to usernames in the Chat log display area.

At IU, a course number an be associated with many sections, so it would not be useful to know just the course number if searching by course. However, if the administrator were searching by username, the course number would be more relevant because most likely the user would only be associated with one course (in the situation of a student). The become user tool is useful to super administrators, but this tool cannot be given to campus and department admins due to the nature of the tool.

column167: All done - this should be verified with a new database, etc.
column171: Not sure where we left all this, Savitha - would like to close it. If we could get a nightly trunk with the enabled setting I could verify.
column181:
A tool property (enableReorder) and a sakai property (sakai.announcement.reorder) is added to control the appearance of reorder in announcement. It is made such that the tool property(tp) always overrides the sakai property (sp).
By default enableReorder is empty and sakai.announcement.reorder is false. The following shows the pattern of properties-

Tp-null/empty| sp-false/not set| result- reorder absent
Tp-null/empty| sp-true | result- reorder present
Tp-false | sp-false/not set | result- reorder absent
Tp-false | sp-true | result- reorder absent
Tp- true | sp-false/not set | result- reorder present
Tp-true | sp-true | result- reorder present

Also there is a database change, where there is addition of a column "MESSAGE_ORDER" of type integer in "ANNOUCEMENT_MESSAGE" table

merged changes from branch to trunk in announcement (r81227) and message (r81228) project.
column185:
the announcement_message schema changes associated with SAK-8005 Closed r81227 require conversion scripts for both MySQL and Oracle added to reference/docs/conversion/sakai_2_8_0_*_conversion.sql for both Oracle and MySQL so that one can upgrade from 2.7.1 to 2.8.0 without error.

See https://source.sakaiproject.org/viewsvn/announcement/trunk/announcement-impl/impl/src/sql/mysql/sakai_announcement.sql?r1=59338&r2=81227

I've added the missing scripts to trunk reference/docs/conversion/sakai_2_8_0_mysql_conversion.sql

– SAK-8005 Closed
alter table ANNOUNCEMENT_MESSAGE add column MESSAGE_ORDER int(11) default null;

drop index IE_ANNC_MSG_ATTRIB on ANNOUNCEMENT_MESSAGE;
create index IE_ANNC_MSG_ATTRIB on ANNOUNCEMENT_MESSAGE (DRAFT, PUBVIEW, OWNER, MESSAGE_ORDER);

drop index ANNOUNCEMENT_MESSAGE_CDD on ANNOUNCEMENT_MESSAGE;
create index ANNOUNCEMENT_MESSAGE_CDD on ANNOUNCEMENT_MESSAGE (CHANNEL_ID, MESSAGE_DATE, MESSAGE_ORDER, DRAFT);

These changes need to be merged to the 2.8.x conversion scripts.

column1: [SAK-7877] Behavior Change for "Release Grades" function
column6:
In the current system, if an instructor saves a draft of an assignment he or she is in the process of grading, and then clicks "Release Grades", the grade is still sent to the student.

1. Instructor - create an assignment
2. Student - submit the assignment
3. Instructor - enter a grade and comments for assignment, click "Preview", then click "Save draft"
4. Instructor - click "Release Grades"
5. Student - grade is displayed

The desired behavior from our perspective would be for ONLY grades that were RETURNED and not SAVED as a Draft. It seems that the option to SAVE as a Draft implies that the grading is still in progress and should not be returned back to the student when "Release Grades" is chosen.

A work around that may give more flexibility to this problem would be to allow the instructor the ability to set preferences for the Release Grades option, such that they can choose to release all grades or only returned grades.

This was originally bug SAK-3719 Closed
column10: Behavior Change for "Release Grades" function

column1: [SAK-3754] Feedback problem
column6: When creating an assessment, we need the feedback set to give the students feedback only AFTER they have submitted. With 2.0.1, we achieved this by setting the feedback to "Show at a later date" and setting that date to be the time the assessment was published. While attempting the assessment, the student would not see any feedback. When they submitted, they could see what was correct and not to fix it for the next attempt. In 2.1.1, the students can see the feedback BEFORE submitting. Thus, they can keep changing thier answer until the feedback tells them that they have it correct. This defeats the purpose of allowing 3 submissions.

column1: [SAK-7970] Instructors should be able to assign site-specific aliases to users
column6:
Currently, a user has one ID, one email address, one name, and so on across all sites within a Sakai installation. There should be a way to set site-specific user data which will be displayed instead of the defaults in the context of a given site. In particular, course-site-specific aliases should be able to override a student's user ID.

Use Cases:

  • In a Trade Bargaining course, students are assigned country names. For the duration of the course they represent that country in all activities within the course, including voting, chatting, and discussions. In the equivalent course site, students are identified by country name aliases in all tools.

===

Original description:

We have a Trade Bargaining course where students are assigned country names and for the duration of the course they represent that country in all activities within the course.
For the last few years they've been using an online environment to do their bargaining, voting, chatting and discussions. Having access to an online environment has become essential to the course and they won't be able to use Sakai without this feature.
The alias should be course specific.
Also the students don't choose their alias, it is assigned to them
column10: Instructors should be able to assign site-specific aliases to users

column1: [SAK-7795] Aggregate External and Internal Schedule Information
column6:
The ability to aggregate or combine schedule information from external sources with a site's Schedule. Aggregation should be possible on an institution-wide basis or on an individual site basis.

Use Case:

  • An item related to a course is added to a campus wide calendaring system. When the students view the calendar for the related course, they see items entered within Sakai and also the campus wide items that are displayed through the provider.
  • Combine local and external calendar events to allow institution-wide dates (academic calendar, holidays, etc.) to be aggregated with local site-specific events.
  • An instructor may wish to include his schedule from an external calendar system in his courses so students know when he is free.

column1: [SAK-7240] TurnItIn integration
column6:
Our institution subscribes to TurnItIn's plagiarism detection services (http://www.turnitin.com/static/plagiarism.html).
It can be accessed via a web browser but we've also integrated it with our home-grown CMS. In other words when staff creates an assignment in our CMS it automatically create an assignment in TurnItIn with the same name.
When students submit to our CMS the papers are automatically also submitted to TurnItIn and when the submission reports from TurnItIn are made available, they are accessible from our CMS.
Some staff has become so used to this feature, since it is easier and far less work than using TurnItIn directly, which will make the decision to migrate to Sakai a difficult one.

column1: [SAK-8061] Administrators should be able to prevent users from unjoining a site
column6:
Currently, any user who is added to a site is able to remove themselves from a site via "Unjoin" in the Membership tool.

It should be possible for administrators to enforce centralized management of site membership by setting a site to be non-unjoinable.

Use Cases:

  • Membership of a course site is manually administered and should not be changed without notice. When creating the course site, the administrator leaves "Can be joined by anyone" unchecked and checks the "Members cannot unjoin themselves" option. If a student or TA wants to leave the site, they must submit a request.

column1: [SAK-7921] Signup for a specific event within a course and assignment context
column6:
Certain courses require individuals or teams to complete tasks in (for example) lab settings, where there are is a limited number of lab spaces available (and/or any other constrained resource, e.g. items of equipment).

Students are therefore required to signup for a specific event. Applicable business rules may include:

  • Students must sign up in teams of up to X students. Team leaders may sign up themselves and their team members, or individuals may join an existing team which is not full.
  • The event may be held in multiple sessions. Only a limited number of students can be accommodated in one session (e.g. a computer lab only has 20 PCs, but there are 60 students in the course, so students have a choice of 3 sessions).

This use case is more complex than students signing up for Sections, in that the events are once-off rather than repeating, and additional business rules may apply.

Lecturers can view the signup sheet for a session (in printable form), lock the session (to prevent additional signups), and enter a mark for all participants / teams in a session (submitted to Gradebook).
column10: Signup for a specific event within a course and assignment context

column6:

Attachment handling should be revised to address these issues. Storing attachments within the site folder structure within a protected/hidden folder may be a good starting point.

column1: [SAK-39464] Ability to hide a folder while allowing access to files inside it
column6:
In some cases it may be desirable to hide a folder, while still making files inside it accessible.

For example, a course site owner may wish to include various images in the Wiki, but doesn't want a 'WikiImages' folder visible to students browsing the site.

Folders (optionally files) should therefore have an attribute which can be set by someone with appropriate permissions on the folder, viz. 'Hidden'. Hidden folders are displayed to users who have update permissions on the folder, but are not displayed to users who have read-only access.
column10: Ability to hide a folder while allowing access to files inside it
column19: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
column44: Relates to SAK-7988 Closed which concerns the ability to make visible, or invisible, a file/folder.
column48: When/if this is implemented, we will need to disambiguate (verb for the day!) the two meanings of 'hidden', i.e. as currently supported in Resources, hidden = completely inaccessible (can't see, can't access), vs hidden in this sense (which matches for example usage in Windows), which is can't see but can access.
column52: Stephen, Harriet: The ability for a site maintainer to hide a folder in resources currently exists. Those with access roles cannot see the folder, but the site maintainer is able to see it (though it is grayed out) and access its contents. Or am I misunderstanding something?
column56:
Yes, this is 'hidden' as in the folder is not visible to access users when browsing Resources, but the resources inside it are accessible to access uses (e.g. via direct URL from an html or wiki page).

The currently 'hidden' implementation removes access completely.

The required usage here is more like hidden files on a Windows drive or Novell volume for example - you can't see them but may still be able to read them. (Novell has distinct permissions for this, R = Read, F = File scan, i.e. visible).
column60:

column1: [SAK-7772] Gradebook options to support moderating grades across sections
column6:
In large courses (e.g. 500+ students) with many groups/sections and many different people grading assignments (e.g. TAs), institutional assessment policy may require that grades are moderated across groups, i.e. the grading behaviour of different graders should be consistent, and if not, grades possibly adjusted.

To facilitate this, the gradebook should provide a display and export option to produce a table for each assignment showing by group, the TA, and the highest, lowest and average grade given.

This allows a course convenor or assessment moderator to determine if grading has been consistent across groups, and to apply moderation strategies if required.

(The above is in US terminology; in South Africa, grades = marks, TAs = Tutors).

column1: [SAK-7908] Hierarchy and date ranges for Syllabus
column6:
Syllabus currently provides a reorderable flat view of items. In many cases, lecturers wish to group items according to:

1. Theme
2. Timeslot (e.g. weeks)

Syllabus should therefore be able to support hierarchies (either unlimited or to depth 3), and some relationship of items to dates, for example if an item is a Lecture, it would have a specific day associated with it. If an item is a week (Week 3), it may have a start and end date.

Syllabus item dates could optionally be added to the Schedule (Calendar). The Syllabus display could also be optimized to show current or forthcoming (near future) items, e.g. Current Week, Forthcoming lectures.

column1: [SAK-7971] Bidirectional email gateway for Message Forums
column6:
In many cases, users wish to receive discussion items by email rather than logging in to a website daily or more often. Email Archive provides a way of using email discussion, but is too simple for many applications.

Users should therefore have the ability to participate in Forum discussions as if they were email-based mailing lists, i.e. subscribe to a discussion at various levels (forum, topic or thread). Once subscribed, user's are sent relevant forum postings.

Each email has an appropriate reply address allowing the user to reply to the message by email (in which case the message is inserted into the forum), and also has links which take the user directly to that thread in the forums tool (subject to the usual authentication).

Users can manage their email subscriptions with the forum tool, again either at a forum / topic / thread level, or by managing a list of all current subscriptions for the site.

A typical use case for this would be a student who is reviewing course resources at the end of a course, views a resource (for example an image in Resources) and wishes to review the discussion about that resource which took place somewhere in the discussion forums (which now have a very large number of messages, such that it's impractical to read through them all again).

column1: [SAK-8129] JSF Widget Cleanup
column6:
One of the original visions of Sakai was to delegate much of the implementation of the presentation abstraction to JSF components.

Many projects have used JSF and used a blend of Sakai widgets and their own widgets.

We need to go through a carful effort of bringing these widgets back together so as to end up with a richer set of Sakai widgets so that we can use widgets across tools.

This is often a daunting task because it is more difficultt to write a highly generic variant of a widget versus one which is used in a single place - so some careful architecting is needed to be done in this effort.

We need to refine the Sakai Architecture (likely the Entity Model) in order to support the workflow needs of a learning design engine such as LAMS or Coppercore. The requirements these engines have range from discovery of entities, the timed use of entities during Learning Design experiences, and the retrieval of information from entities.

An instructor wants to be able to create a workflow in a Sakai site. Once this support was added they could use a learning design and workflow engine to create a workflow and make it part of their Sakai site.

column1: [SAK-8111] Improve support for Hibernate - Move hibernate aspects out of shared/lib
column6:
Currently when a component uses Hibernate all of the Hibernate aspects of the component must move into shared/lib because of class loader issues. This also causes some problems when hibernate based components call each other.

This will require some careful thought to come up with a solution and then may require all of the Sakai components which use Hibernate to make some modifications to make use of the new pattern of Hibernate usage. Because of the need for release-wide coordination and the potentially large QA effort, this is something that the community should prioritize.

This may be combined with an update to Hibernate-3 and possibly a move to the latest Spring version.

column56: When considering this issue, keep in mind that IMS Enterprise Services v1 was largely unsuccessful in its goal of easing integration between systems like an SIS and an LMS. The successor to the IMS Enterprise Services v1 specification is the IMS Learning Information Services v2 (LISv2). There is a complete reference implementation of all the SIS -> LMS data services in the Sakora project in Contrib. See http://confluence.sakaiproject.org//x/BAACAg for more information. If we want to have LISv2 included in the Sakai distribution, we should consider adopting the Sakora work into the main distribution. This will not happen for 2.7 at this point, but could be considered for 2.8.

column1: [SAK-7907] Add Hierarchy Capability to the Framework
column6: This will add a generic hierarchy backbone within Sakai and allow sites, and other objects to be associated with theis hierarchy. The primary end-user visible aspect of this will be the ability to have sub-sites, or sites within sites. Over time, tools may begin to use the hierarchy capability to organize their own objects.
column10: Add Hierarchy Capability to the Framework
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44: Would it be possible to restate the requirement in terms of its end goal rather than in terms of its implementation? That is: "Add ability to have sub-sites, or sites within sites." I'm concerned that specifying a generic design before the specific functional requirements may interfere with clarifying and optimizing the most common use cases.
column48:
Some preliminary views on hierarchy from Columbia's course management team. We can also supply some more specific cases, if necessary, to articulate this.

  • site hierarchy: Institutionally driven hierarchy, based on school, department, division, subject code, etc. This allows customization of appearance (skin, layout), default tool selection, and administrative access privileges. A pertinent example is our current CMS's course evaluation module that allows school- and department-wide evaluations and surveys.
  • content hierarchy: The ability to create sites and sites within sites, using user-based tools that automatically connect and embed one site within another. (One open question is whether you allow content to be "blended" as when two Intro sections get merged together. From some previous experience, we think this should be carefully considered with regard to support, implementation, and ease of use.)
  • tool hierarchy: the ability to create sites that have tools based on user-based decisions. For example, a user could design a single site template, then use that site as the starting point for all other sites.
column52: Seth, by all means, please attach your specific use cases here; the more information the better!
column56:
Thanks, Seth. Again, though, I wonder if could we split the functional / administrative requirements from the assumption that anything modeled by a tree structure should be bundled in one place. Otherwise, I'm afraid that we risk polluting our analysis of the problem and then providing the wrong solution.

We might describe your first "view" as requiring "access to and use of education enterprise organizational data by site management, authorization, and other Sakai services". There we're not talking about a tree of objects all of the same type, but a rich source of many different types of information, which happen to include some institutionally-defined person memberships and roles. This is the area targeted by the Course Management WG, and I hope we'll be able to wring lots of free labor out of your team.

The second is talking about web subsites, with some TBD functionality for inheriting or restricting authorizations and views down a pseudo-directory-tree. This is a known need, but I don't think any work group is specifically targeting it yet.

The third is a bit harder for me to get. I understand your example: allow user-designed site templates, which would presumably be easier to work with than making a "generic" site and then copying it to new sites, and which would presumably come into play during automatic creation of sites via enterprise integration. But I'm not sure how to generalize further than that.
column60: From a usage data perspective, it would be useful to represent what is described here as a site hierarchy in the URLs. That way one can easily report on usage within a particular local enterprise organizational scheme by simply looking for a string in the URL, instead of having to look up individual site ids and manually group them.
column64: During our user studies around course management, we've seen that some users of Moodle use Seth's 3rd use case (tool hiearchy) as a way to deal with sections. So, for a langauge class where there are numerous sections, all taught by seperate instructors but with the same basic curriculum, they create a site once and duplicate for each section. So they start with the same content, but once the semester starts each instructor may utilize the site a little differently. The interesting part is that in many cases there is also shared content (and not shared content) throughout the semester.
column132: In Stellar, we have (using Seth's nomenclature) site hierarchy (with the site hierarchy represented in the URLs), content hierarchy (for sections), not really tool hierarchy. I can (plan to) give our experience of what turned out to actually be useful, what we didn't get around to implementing but wish we had, and what we wound up implementing in different ways.
column143:
This is a slightly disjoint comment, but may be relevant, as it is based on real usage of a VLE in 3 UK institutions. (Oxford, UHI, Manchester, Leeds etc) The VLE is boddington.

In Boddington hierarchy is the primary organisation at a site level, so that worksites are organised in that hierachy (as per Seths site hierarchy case). In addition both tools and entities are placed in this hierarchy. Tools are placed with some control, so that chaos does not follow.... but entities like announcements or resources may be placed within the organising hierarchy.

In addition to the oranisational aspects of this hierarchy implementation, permissions also follow the ancestor/decendant paths where permission are inherited from ancesestors (or not). How this might relate to Sakai worksites is not clear, even if it controlled functionality within the hierachy.

In this case a hierarchy service would, in conjuction with an aggregator organise a view onto Sakai worksites, their tools and entities that was not the tradtional flat organisation we see in the current Charon aggregator.
column150:
Add a UI to display sites in a hierarchy. This all centers around
a new per-site property (sakai:parent-id). This allows the construction
of a hierarchy by having child sites point to parent sites.

This is a latent feature with zero UI impact unless it is truned on
by the addition of a property.

For more info see
https://source.sakaiproject.org/svn//reference/trunk/docs/architecture/sakai_pseudo_hierarchy.doc

See the above document for some next steps.

column1: [SAK-3752] Table macro is too basic
column6:
I've had more than a few requests for more complex table support. People would like to be able to have tables without borders and/or headers. There have been queries about colspans and rowspans.

The major problem is how to do this without encouraging non-semantic behaviour. Also what is a sensible syntax?
column10: Table macro is too basic
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44:
Having thought about this the requirements are as follows:

We need to be able to mark a table as without borders.
We should be able to the set a table's class. (This could be done another way: see block macro.)
Cells should be markable as th cells.
Cells need colspans and rowspans.
Cell data should be allowed to be more than one line long.
column48: Please see the attached file for suggested syntax and example
column52: I'm not so sure we want to go down this path. While I can see that the proposed syntax is learnable, at a minimum it would need to be an 'advanced' option as many users will struggle with simple table syntax at first...
column56: People require more complex tables, there is no question of this. Perhaps the above syntax is too much. (In fact my current thoughts are to use the wikipedia syntax, which for some reason I couldn't find when I was looking for it!) I'm not suggesting that we change the basic functionality of the table macro, only that there is a complex mode for those that wish to go down that route.
column60: See the wiki pipe markup in http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Help:Table
column64: [Bulk Comment] This issue is reported as affecting Sakai 1.0, 1.5, 2.0, 2.1, and/or 2.2; however, it is not reported as affecting a currently supported version of Sakai (2.3 or 2.4). If this issue is indeed still a concern for a supported version of Sakai, please do re-open the issue and add the appropriate 2.3 and/or 2.4 version to the Affects Version field. (Please do not remove existing Affects Versions when adding the new Affects Versions.)
column132:
I would be happy to have a "No Border" feature and a way to mark cells as headers.

I use Wikidot.com sometimes, and I really like the way they code headers:

  • a normal cell is between pipes, just like RWiki
  • a header cell has a tilde ~ right after the pipe: |~

So the code looks like this:

~ Header 1 ~ Header 2 Not a header
Normal cell ~ Header cell within table Normal cell

Oh, and another thing...

Could we make the default table border light gray, and on all borders (not just the upper border of the cell), and make the header style a light gray background with bold text?

column1: [SAK-7904] Users should be able to upload a photo in Profile
column6:
Presently, if a user wishes to add her photo to her profile, she needs to do the following:

  • Upload an image into Resources
  • Make the image public (share it)
  • Add the URL of the image in Profile

To make this simpler for users, Profile should allow users to upload a photo, rather than specifying a URL. The uploaded image should also be automatically resized for an appropriate display size. Optionally, the original image could be retained along with the resized image.

Use Case:

  • A TA wants to make his photo available to students, instructors, and other TAs in a course site. He goes to "Profile", clicks on "Upload Picture", and selects a JPG file on his desktop. The graphics file is uploaded and displayed to users who have authorization to see his personal information.

column1: [SAK-8027] Instant messaging support
column6:
There are many use cases for good support for and integration with instant messaging technologies (targetting specifically Jabber/XMPP). These include:

  • Notifications and alerts by IM
  • Replacement for chat service
  • Enhanced presence awareness
  • Supporting collaborative activities

Minimal integration would include IM-capable Announcements and notification service, updated user profile and preferences to allow IM settings and options.

See initial work on this topic in Confluence: http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/confluence/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=4580

column1: [SAK-8140] SMS (text messaging) integration
column6:
In a number of countries, a very high percentage of students have cell phones (mobile phones) with text messaging capability (e.g. > 95% of students at University of Cape Town).

There are many applications for using text messaging to communicate with Sakai users both with the existing & future toolset, for example announcements and notifications, and for interactive learning applications such as submitting content or questions to possible tools such as a FAQ, Glossary tool, Forums or Wiki page by SMS.

Supporting SMS capability in Sakai requires:

  • Profile tool to allow students to enter a cellphone number
  • User preference settings to opt in or opt out of SMS notifications
  • Integration with (minimally) Announcements and notification service
  • Site option settings
  • A service for passing outgoing messages to a gateway
  • A service for accepting incoming messages from a gateway
  • Quota management capabilities for setting volume limits for sites and users

The service and options available need to be flexible enough to cater for inter alia different types of SMS gateways in use, and different business models applicable in different countries (e.g. sender pays, receiver pays, etc.).

column1: [SAK-7771] Users should be given a way to log in and reset lost passwords
column6:
When user accounts are explictly added to Sakai, the new user will receive an email with their password. However if a user loses his/her password, there is no way for the user to recover a password (e.g. by having a new one emailed to them).

This is an important capability which needs to be in core Sakai. Otherwise it creates significant support issues as the guest userbase grows.

Use Cases:

  • A visiting scholar will be contibuting content to a project site from her own institution. A Sakai user account is added for her based on her email address, and she's added to the site. A month later, she's ready to contribute but no longer remembers her password. After failing to log on, she clicks on a "Forgot Password?" link. After verifying a password reset, she's then emailed instructions for logging in, with the understanding that she must immediately change her password after logging in.

Solutions separately implemented by Rutgers and UNISA are described in the comments.
column10: Users should be given a way to log in and reset lost passwords
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44: Stephan, could you describe how the Rutgers and UNISA solutions work from the user perspective?
column48:
There are 2 approaches: on both, the user has a 'lost password' link available on the login page, or perhaps in Help. The user enters his/her email address and clicks a 'reset my password' button.

Note that this requires the user to have a valid email address for this to work, and additionally sites may also want to restrict this functionality to user types which are internally authenticated (rather than authenticated against LDAP, etc.).

Approach 1:
As implemented and described by Rutgers,

"On the main sakai page, before logging in, go to "New Account". There should be a new button on the bottom labelled "send password email". Specify the username of a guest (which must be an email address) in the userid field, and click the button. You should get an email with a URL that will log you in. At that point you can change your password or other information. (The token in the URL is actually the password MD5'd twice, the second time with a salt.)"

i.e. the user is emailed a URL containing a token which takes the user to a page allowing the user to enter a new password.

Approach 2:
The user is emailed a new password, e.g. a randomly-generated numeric password.

Approach 1 is probably preferable, as it provides more safeguards against abuse (e.g. someone entering someone else's password in 'lost password' and resetting the other user's password, which would not be a security vulnerability, but could be disruptive and annoying to the 'victim' user).

Another complication would be in cases where more than 1 user has the same email address but distinct usernames - assuming that 'lost password' is checking on account email address as well as or instead of account id (for guest accounts, initially account id = email address, but users could change their email address to something different later).

Approach 1 would also work better in that instance, as it would prevent user A from changing user B's password where both share the same email address. Alternately the 'lost password' form could require a username in addition to an email address.
column52: Reviewed by Worksite & Admin Tools.
column56: UCT has implemented Approach 2 above as an RSF tool which can be placed in the Gateway site. Code to follow in contrib/uct/.
column60: See http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/confluence/display/RPASS

column1: [SAK-7883] Online surveys and course evaluations
column6:
There are 2 use cases for a tool which can be used for surveys:

1. Research and collaboration groups using Sakai who wish to survey participants or a broader sample of people online

2. Course evaluations

This capability is similar to that currently provided by T&Q, but with some important differences, e.g.:

  • No correct answer
  • No references to grading, assessment, etc.
  • Support for presenting and exporting results in various ways

It is expected that the easiest way of achieving this would be to extend T&Q.

Expanded upon by Owen McGrath and edited slightly by Kristol Hancock:
In terms of the survey-ish uses cases (e.g., group collaboration, formative or summative course evaluation) there would seem to be an opportunity right away to improve the use interface by optionally hiding references to scores and scoring, as Stephen mentioned. I have also been wondering for a while if it might make more sense to liberate "survey" from being just a question type. It would make more sense to have "survey" as a general assessment type that allows for a wide range of questions types such as Short Answer/Essay, Fill-in-the-blank, and the scale type questions currently offered by the survey question type.
column10: Online surveys and course evaluations
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44:
For end of course evaluations a couple of features make for better turnout and easier management:

1) End of course evaluations should be enabled or disabled by a Sakai admin toward the end of the semester.
2) When the admin enables the feature the following occurs:
-When the student logs in they are prompted to fill out end of course evals for specified courses ( the Sakai admin should be able to configure whether the student has to complete the evals before continuing into a course or whether they can click through )
-The prompts continue until the student has either finished all the evals or the Sakai admin disables the feature.
column48: Another use case for surveys is in-class assessment; such as surveys using clicker or responder systems. Extending T&Q would fit nicely with that, as students can already be in Sakai taking their notes on the Power Point lecture slides posted for class and chatting with the teaching assisstants in class via Chat. Sometimes such assessment is done anonymously just to get a feel for where the class and instruction are at, and sometimes it is important to keep track of who filled out the survey so points can be awarded as a way to encourage (and take) attendence.
column52: In terms of the survey-ish uses cases (e.g., group collaboration, formative or summative course evaluation) there would seem to be an opportunity right away to improve the use interface by optionally hiding references to scores and scoring, as Stephen mentioned. I have also been wondering for a while if it might make more sense to liberate "survey" from being a just question type. Would it make more sense to have "survey" as a general assessment type that allows for a wide range of questions types such as Short Answer/Essay, Fill-in-the-blank, and the scale type questions currently offered by the survey question type?
column56: Owen, that is a good point and I believe is the mentality behind assigning 0 points to a question type such as short answer/essay or fill-in-the-blank. This way, an assessment author can make any question type a 'survey' question. However, I do agree with the need to have a 'survey' as a general assessment type. This would negate the need to assign 0 points to a question type.
column60: Ready for voting.
column64:
Just want to "second" the need for a "forcing function" that would require users to complete a "survey" and allow the admin to configure it to not allow them to access their course until this was completed. We evaluation all of our online courses and found that when we made this "optional" and simply provided a link to the survey, response rates were in the 20-40% range. When we moved to a "forcing" model in which we forced the student to complete the evaluation, the response rate went up to 90-95%, which mirrors the response rate we get on our paper evaluations (an important factor as faculty insist that the rates be the same in order to make them valid).

Finally, another "use case" would be for surveying students at the start of a course...this can help gauge prior knowledge and also help when grouping students for projects.

Thanks, Josh

column1: [SAK-8039] Anonymous poll tool
column6:
A simple but useful tool is one which can quickly survey opinion on a specific topic - a poll tool.

The tool should provide a simple multiple-choice question, allowing respondents to choose one or possibly multiple options.

Aggregate results are immediately available to participants.

The poll tool should be optionally integrated with discussion (ideally targetted at Message Centre) so that it's possible to follow a link to a topic / thread about the poll. There may also be other integration points and features, e.g. ability to send an email notification of a new poll, or automatically add an announcement about the poll (with a link to take the poll and/or view results).

Some screenshots from an existing CMS illustrating the basic idea are attached.
column10: Anonymous poll tool
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44: This seems like something that could be done using Samigo.
column48:
Maybe. But the overheads of using Samigo at present (in terms of complexity) are such that probably no-one would ever do so. So I think of this as squarely in the "new tool" arena, though it's possible that Samigo could be modified to have an ultra-simple mode for this application.

The use case is quite different to assessments or formal surveys - these polls are for informally and quickly testing opinion or gathering simple results over a period of time.

column56: Such a new tool would make for a nice web-based replacement to "responder" or "clicker" systems for in-class polling/quizzing as well.

column1: [SAK-3750] Fix warning for no correct answer in multiple choice authoring
column6:
When you're creating a multiple-choice question with multiple correct answers, if you try to save the question with no correct answer you see this warning (see screenshot):

"You must select at least one correct answer and make sure those answer texts are not empty."

It's a small thing, but conspicuous. Can we reword it to something like:

" - You must select at least one correct answer

  • Correct answer fields cannot be empty"
column10: Fix warning for no correct answer in multiple choice authoring
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44:
The text is currently showing as -

"You must select one correct Answer. Correct answer field can not be empty."

I think the word 'field' should be pluralized to say 'fields' as in the case of multiple choice questions there will always be more than one answer field.
column48:
Let's separate out these two error messages.

If you try to save a multiple choice question with no correct answer, the validation error should tell you:

"You must choose at least one correct answer."

If you try to save a multiple choice question with an empty correct answer choice, the validation error should say:

"Please enter the text for selection (letter)."

This is the same error you get when you leave a blank answer choice in the middle of the question. We can just re-use it for this error.

Does that work?
column52:
We also have a small regression. If you edit a correct answer choice once, after that you can leave it empty and Samigo won't notice.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Create a new multiple choice multiple-correct question with answers A, B, C and D. Mark B and C correct. Don't type anything in the C answer box, though.

2. Save the question. You'll get an error because C is empty.

3. Type something in the C answer box and then delete it, so it's still empty (and marked correct). Save the question again.

4. This time it will save without an error. If you preview the question, you'll see that C is empty.
column56:
The separate warnings are now in place and correct, and the regression bug is gone too. Thanks!

There's just one new problem: if you leave an answer choice blank, you get the warning twice (see screenshot).

It's not terrible, but it would be good if it showed up only once.

column1: [SAK-3749] Need a way to limit how many attachments are selected in file picker

column44:
Provide implementation so tools calling ResourcesAction as attachment helper can set the following state attribute with an Integer vale to indicate the maximum number of items that can be attached:

/**

  • The name of the state attribute for the maximum number of items to attach.
  • The attribute value will be an Integer, usually CARDINALITY_SINGLE or CARDINALITY_MULTIPLE.
    */
    public static final String STATE_ATTACH_CARDINALITY = "resources.attach_cardinality";

The usual values will be:

/** A constant indicating maximum of one item can be attached. */
public static final Integer CARDINALITY_SINGLE = new Integer(1);

/** A constant indicating any the number of attachments is unlimited. */
public static final Integer CARDINALITY_MULTIPLE = new Integer(Integer.MAX_VALUE);
column48: The state attribute ResourcesAction.STATE_ATTACH_CARDINALITY can be used to set maximum cardinality to ResourcesAction.CARDINALITY_SINGLE or ResourcesAction.CARDINALITY_MULTIPLE or any positive Integer value.

column1: [SAK-8099] Accessibility--Title and Content Frames should be combined
column6:
Separate title and content frames create a situation where tool headings are often redundant and navigation is cumbersome. For example, if a screen reader user has his JAWS settings on default, he will hear the following description:

Beginning of announcements title frame
Announcements title frame
Help
End of announcements title frame
Beginning of announcements content frame
Announcements content frame
Add
Merge
Options
Permissions
Announcements heading one
column10: Accessibility--Title and Content Frames should be combined
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44: This is a portal issue per Anthony and Gonzalo's comments. However, it is part of a larger issue on the use of iFrames in Sakai. As such, fixing this problem may involve significant changes to the Sakai UI strategy. Fixing this is further out than 2.2.
column48:
Is it really necessary to tie this to the larger issue of iFrames and Sakai UI strategy? My preference is to resolve this problem and then deal with the larger issues. Otherwise, I am concerned that this fix will continue to languish.

BTW, I am no fan of iFrames, but this would significantly improve the experience for persons using screen readers. Let's move on this and settle the iFrames issue post 2.2.
column52:
This is also a performance issue, not only an accessibility issue. The requirement to have a separate iframe for the tool title introduces at least one additional http request for every page, adding to page load time. This may not be noticeable on a local LAN, but is significant on dialup connections, and accessing remote Sakai instances.

It should preferably be resolved for 2.2.
column56:
In 2.2 we removed most of the Iframes so there is now only 1, the tool itself

In 2.4 we have JSR-168 so there are potentially no iframes.

Since the orriginal request has been satisfied I am closing this Feature Request.

If there is a demand for specific tools to operate in a flat portal with no iframes I would suggest a new feature request to the tool in quetion to make it provide a JSR-168 based tool that can be exposed flat with no iframes.

column1: [SAK-7798] Document Versioning
column6:
Many of our courses involve team projects that involve several people working on the same document. This is awkward to manage without some versioning capability in the Resources tool. I would project that the same thing would be valuable for research collaboration.

Use cases:

  • a collaborator uploads a new file into a location with a file already bearing that name. The new file is stored with a new version number visible through the interface.
  • other collaborators are able to access previous versions of the same document
  • at least one collaborator or manager has the ability to revert the document's version to a previous version.
  • this versioning capability happens consistently through both WebDAV and the web interface

column1: [SAK-3746] tests and quizzes / matching questions not scoring correctly
column6:
I set up an assessment with two matching questions, one with 5 items worth 25 points and one with 4 items worth 20 points. I got three out of five correct on the first question. Logically I should have been rewarded 15/25 points but samigo is only awarding 5/25 points. I got two out of four correct on the second question. Logically I should have been rewarded 10/20 points, but samigo scored it as 0/20. I tested this on the stable instances running 2.1.1.004 (oracle and MySQL)

Steps to reproduce-
Create an assessment with a matching question that has multiple pairings
Publish that assessment, take as a student ensuring that at least 1 or 2 answers in the matching question are answered incorrectly, and submit
Log in as the instructor and the scoring will not reflect the correct number of points.

column1: [SAK-7761] Resource Viewer Tool
column6: The resources tool is cluttered because it has everything needed to create new resources and edit existing resources as well as giving hierarchical access to large resource collections. Lots of people want different views of resources. One common request is the ability to create a list of resources (and possibly other types of entities) related to a particular part of a course or subproject. If we make the resources tool more like that, we break the hierarchical view. Instead, we should make a new tool that is intended as a resource viewer. This tool would focus on making it easier for a site maintainer to create a simple list of resources and format it as they see fit. The list itself would be read-only.
column10: Resource Viewer Tool
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44:
A use case for this tool: An instructor wants to create an item in the "tool" menu (at the left side of the screen) labeled "Week 1" containing a list of resources relevant to the first week's lectures and readings for a course. The instructor adds a "ResourceViewer" tool to the site and names it "Week 1". The instructor then configures the tool. Because the instructor has maintainer permissions for the site, she sees a link labeled "Add" in the global menu for the tool. Clicking the "add" link brings up the resources attachment helper, allowing her to attach a link to any resource she has access to (in any site, if "see all sites" is enabled). It also allows her to create a new attachment. She can add multiple items if she chooses. The items do not have to be in the same folder in the resources tool. Clicking "finish" in the attachment helper returns the instructor to the ResourcesViewer. The item(s) she added are listed there. Next she can format the display. Maybe there's a "format" button in the tool's global menu. That allows her to pick what fields will be shown for each item in the list and maybe even relative font sizes. She can also define an order for the items in the list. The default order should be the order in which items were added to the list, but the maintainer has the ability to sort on any field and rearrange by moving items up or down in the list.

The default view the instructor sees is the same simple view the students see. It's only when she clicks an action in the tool's global menu that she sees additional controls.

Students see a simple flat list of resources (and maybe other types of entities such as discussion threads or assignments). They can click on items to access them. Clicking on a resource should access it through the access servlet. If we provide access to other entity types, we would want to launch them in the "viewer" for that entity type. For example, if there is a link to an assignment, clicking on the link for an assignment would take the student into the assignment tool.
column48: Related to SAK-7892 Closed . Maybe these are alternative descriptions for the same requirement(s)?
column52: Looks like SAK-7892 Closed to me, also like SAK-8112 Closed
column56: Some work that may be relevant to this issue is beginning. See http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/confluence/display/RES/Resources+Viewer.
column60: What is the status of work on the Resource Viewer?
column64:
DITTO!

What is the status of the Resource Viewer (or as named at UW) the Content Viewer?
Is it still an active project?
I had thought it was to be included in 2.4 - but apparently didn't make it...
Many links to Resource Viewer pages result in broken links.
Any chance on getting an official status report on this tool (potential) tool?

Thanks Bunches!
Teresa Collins (Terry)
LMS Administrator (CLEW)
Centre for Teaching & Learning
University of Windsor
column132:
It strikes me that this idea may test Sakai's current navigation structure. It sounds like the vision is that an instructor may add a new page for each week in the term and these show up in the left hand tool navigation bar. 2 potential usability challenges:

1) The list of items in the nav bar gets ever longer. it would be great to keep all main navigation above the fold.
2) Confusion between "Week 2" and Forums for example when as a student I'm asked to add to the discussion topic for this week. Where should I go and do I need to understand under what conditions I go to one versus the other? We want to minimize this kind of navigational thinking for users and allow them to focus on the discussion.

Has there been any discussion about the viewing capability as something that lives within other tools rather than creating a new tool? I haven't thought this through much so mostly think out loud but the first thing that came to mind reading Jim's use case above was that it sounds like a syllabus. We are trying to take contextual viewing needs into account in the Image Gallery Tool, under development at Berkeley. In the context of presenting images to students for study, we are building in the appropriate views like thumbnails, slideshow, etc. As the scenarios for Resource Viewer get fleshed out more, it might be worth thinking about if this kind of functionality could integrate into what's already there.
column143: This tool appears to be similar to Melete. Yes? How is it different?
column150:
The Resources Viewer tool is very simple - it simply displays the contents of a folder in Resources in a more attractive way, showing the description, for example, but not the upload time. Some text can be added to the top of each Resources viewer page, to explain for example, what students are asked to do with the Resources. This makes it obviously very different to Melete. It could have a result similar to the Syllabus tool (in what I understand the US meaning of a Syllabus to be, i.e. a week by week list of objectives and readings) or the Wiki tool, but it would automate the process of attaching resources to weeks, and generally move the focus to the attachments.

As Daphne says, you might then have a tool item for each week in the menu. This has actually been quite popular as an idea with the lecturers at Cambridge, some of whom would rather see 'Week 2' in the list than 'Resources'. However, there comes a point at which you have a lot of items in the menu. (We find this a general problem in Sakai)

We've had a number of disucssions about whether it will be possible to address the problem of 'Week 2' wanting to contain both forums and resources, and have come up with the idea that eventually it would be nice to have all these tools as bits you can drop in to pages. But at the moment we're nowhere near it.
column154:
I'm resolving this because we did actually write the tool during that one week a few years ago, and I think at least a few people are running it in production. I think any future jira's for this can probably finer grained.

I still remember our Breeze session where we worked on it though when I was visiting at UM. That was the most fun I've ever had in a Breeze call.

megacheers.

column1: [SAK-8038] Search across site and sites
column6: A Search capability is needed that allows searching through all content in a site, or through all content in all sites in which the user is a member.
column10: Search across site and sites
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44:
If I understand this correctly

"Content in a site" means Resources/Announcements etc in a site,

Search already does all content in a site, there is a patch in progress to do all sites that I am a member of.

If this meanst All content in the site description, then search does not do this yet.
column48: Yes you understood it correctly. I was asking for the option to control the search to look in just the site I am in, or through all sites in which I am a member. Maybe if the search tool is in a My Workspace the default is all my sites. If in a course/project site, default is just that site, with option to search all or just some subset of my sites.
column52: SAK-8717 Closed allows searching a specified set of sites, but that set is specified by hand. It doesn't automatically add, say, all sites you are a member of to the list. It includes only the current site by default.
column56: One possibly implementation would have the search tool search all member sites if it's placed within a user's My Workspace site. Having a special aggregating functionality has precedence in many tools, such as the Schedule/Calendar tool. The attached patch implements this.
column60:
Before implementing this, I think it would be valuable to clarify scenarios. I think that what users have been asking for here (small sample <10) is a search box in the sense that most large websites have a search box - something in a known place from which they can search all site content. As part of a general request to make Sakai act more like a websiite, they want search to act like a website search. The do not appear to consider each Sakai worksite to be an independent web site and we do not encourage them to think that way. I think this is right, but it means they think of Sakai as a single website and expect search to search the whole site. Now we know that it is more complicated than that because the extent of this larger website that is available to them is smaller than the total content and variable even from day to day as they join and leave worksites or permissions/roles are changed. In thinking about search we should be aware of this issue and consider how to deal with questions like "I could find this yesterday, why can't I find it today?"

All that said, I think the search box wants to be visible to the user at all times (like login/logout) and to return all available results from the users worksites that they have permission to see. Ideally it will not show results they cannot subsequently access, but there are potential arguments around this so e.g. we may in future want something that can show a result from an open site that the user has not yet joined with an indication that they can access the result after joining the site (arguably in this case we could offer them access immediately while pointing out that it is from a site they haven't joined).

I don't favour "place search in myworkspace" if it means I have to click away from the site I am in in order to search, except as a temporary workaround and interim solution. I also don't favour having "Search" do different things in different places - especially if users are not very aware of the differences between locations.

Considering the fact that the current search offers a useful feature of searching only the current worksite, and assuming this represents a valuable processing efficiency as well as a user feature, it is probably useful to retain this as an option - perhaps as a checkbox alongside the search button e.g. "only pages from this course/project site" If display of search results is a sortable list with site location as a sortable heading (optional?), then perhaps 'search this site only' is not necessary as a user feature and only has value if it saves significant processing.
column64:
As become more like "most large websites" then we may also wish to include content from sites that the user isn't a member of but are defined as being public. The problem comes that as we have more matches for content outside of the sites a user is a member of we have more permission checks that are likely to fail. What we don't want to get into the situation is where a search returns 10,000 matches but the user doesn't have permission to view the first 7,000.

My patch in SAK-6703 Closed is probably closer to the request originally made here.
column132: Matthew Bucketts patch has been applied. see linked SAK

column1: [SAK-7837] Selected course site sections should be automatically created and maintained based on external roster feeds
column6:
Use Cases:

  • An instructor creates a course site whose student membership comes from 3 Lecture sections of Psych 100. She chooses to automatically create and populate corresponding visible user groups in her site. Section aware tools then let her see which Lecture section a student is part of, and let her filter and assign students by Lecture section. As students are dropped from or added to the external feeds, they appear in or disappear from the appropriate site sections. The instructor can use Section Info to add internally managed students and TAs to the site sections.
column10: Selected course site sections should be automatically created and maintained based on external roster feeds
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44:
John Leasia's original description:

Along with SAK-7935 Closed and SAK-7953 Closed which add group control to other tools, as an option it would be useful to allow auto creating groups from the roster for each class section that might be in a site via a provider id. For example, if a site contained 3 rosters because the provider id was
2006,3,A,PSYCH,100,[001,002,003]
it would be nice to automatically create a group 001, 002, 003 with the associated rosters, and have those groups change as the enrollment in the given section changes due to drops/adds etc. Instructors could still add students manually to such groups.
column48:
This use case is a major driver for the Course Site Management project which is underway by the CM WG. So far, that project includes the following related requirements, not mentioned by John:

  • The instructor needs more (and more friendly) information about external courses and sections than just a single roster string.
  • Default site section names should be provided but can be overwritten.
  • If the roster feeds come from different courses, the course must be taken into account in the section names.
  • Reconciliation rules must be clearly defined to avoid conflicts between automatic and manual management of memberships.
  • It must be possible for instructors to take over internal management of a section without having to disband the section first.
column52: Reviewed by Worksite & Admin Tools.
column56: This requirement has been fulfilled as of the 2.4 release. Note: it is not yet possible to add internal users to externally defined sections so long as the sections remain externally managed.

column1: [SAK-7790] Sites browsing needs performance improvements, sorting, and direct links to public content
column6:
The legacy tools which browse available sites (including "Worksite Setup" and the Gateway "Sites" tool which shows available sites to visitors) need several improvements.

1) Performance issues need to be taken care of. (Probably a redesign of some underlying services will be needed to achieve this, since the necessary data is currently spread among different tables.)

2) Sorting by "Term" must be supported for course sites. (Making this efficient may also require some service redesign, since the term is not currently exposed as a column in the database.)

3) Visitors should be given a direct link to the public content of a site, if such a page exists.

Use Cases:

  • An instructor logs in, goes to Worksite Setup, and sorts sites by term in order to find course sites from last fall.
  • A new student visits the institution's LMS to see what sort of Sociology classes are being offered. Without logging in, she's able to quickly see a list of this term's sites. She clicks on the "Public Page" link for one and gets an idea of what's being done there.
column10: Sites browsing needs performance improvements, sorting, and direct links to public content
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44: Tied in with this is also the notion of a URL to the public content, so that a URL can be given out that gets users to the page that contains the list of public info.
column48: John, do you have any information on what exactly the performance issues are an any suggested fixes at this point?
column52: Glenn knows what the performance problems are. One is that term is a property rather than a column in the db, so it is expensive to do any sorts. I think the data displayed on that page comes from several different tables, so the joins when searching cause lots of perfomance problems.
column56:
John Leasia's original description:

The current Sites tool (sakai.sitebrowser) has had performance issues such that we had to remove it from the UM installatiion. We need this tool back essentially as is but with a restructuring that eliminates performance problems it was causing. Included is the need in this tool as well as others (Worksite Setup for example) to be able to sort by Term when term is one of the columns in a list.

Without the tool, there isn't a way for non authenticated users to get at content earmarked as public.

There doesn't need to be any design as the tool exists and has been in use.

column1: [SAK-3736] CLONE -True/False question doesnt remember answer
column6:
At our pilot server at Stockholm university. A teacher raported it to me and I've reproduced it:

Create a test/quizz with a True/False question with point value set to 1.0. I also included a multiple choice question (also 1.0) to have something to work with. Add an access student, log in and take the published quizz, answer the quizz with correct answers. Submit for grading.

Back to the maintain account, look at scores, the point value for the T/F question is't counted, it's 0.

Also, I found out that the mark for the correct answer on the T/F question wasn't recorded/remembered. It was left blank, so maybe that is what cased it.

Can anyone else reproduce this?

column1: [SAK-3735] Permission to control who can trigger Resources notifications
column6:
The system currently behaves as expected for the original issue report:

"We've had a problem report from a faculty user who has turned on the content.new permission for the Student role in his course site. When this permission is on, his students can see the Email Notification option and have been choosing to send email notifications that they have added Resources. However, the faculty user says that he hasn't changed their permissions in Email Archive and all the Student role is enabled to do there is read emails. So how is it that by being able to post Resources they can now email to the course site when they aren't enabled to explicitly in Email Archive?"

The requested feature which could help in this situation is to have a permission which controls who can trigger Resource notifications. A role that did not have this permission, such as Student, would still be able to post resources (content.new), but would not have the permission to trigger an email notification.
column10: Permission to control who can trigger Resources notifications
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44:
Michelle, this is how the system works. Sending email out for notification has nothing to do with a person's email archiving permissions. These are two completely separate systems.

Anyone who can post a resource to the system has the choice of doing notification.
column48:
Email notifications are distinct from Email Archive, which accepts incoming mail to the course site and distributes it to participants.

So the behaviour described seems correct, and it seems that to resolve this the way the site owner would like may require a new permission, e.g. content.sendnotifications ?
column52:
This user, in any case, doesn't seem to understand the difference - "it's all email, and I don't want my students to be able to send any." I know that the notifications aren't stored in Email Archive, but this is a splitting-hairs difference to most folks.

I like Stephen's suggestion of a short-term fix by adding a new permission in Resources to control the ability to send notifications.

column1: [SAK-3729] A better search interface
column6:
Search
Definition

  • Current search uses boolean and full text search, with no summary
  • Search needs to be more like a search engine

Implementation

  • We think plugging in Lucene will do this
    o A modified nutch might be quicker
  • Search output is list of results with context (like MediaWiki search produces)
  • Index should be built when content is changed
    o Seperate search engine indexer thread that works on a list of pages to index
    o Pages to index added to the list as edits are made
    o Output of indexing is stored in the database as blobs
    o Indexing contains metadata so that one search engine can pre-subselect the context of the search
    o On search result the preview version is a non html - text only string with the matching words highlighted

Issues

  • Indexing should index cachable rendered content, this means that non cachable

column60:
Section support and authz based on authz groups is in place. Parts of the UI are not complete at the moment.

To activate you place a

{sakai-sections}

macro on the page which will generate a list of Sections. This macro has some parameters (see the help_page in rwiki or put a

{list-of-macros}

on a page to find out what they are. Parameters enable using UUID's of the sections rather than names and filtering based on the category name.

Note although the authz mechanism will work with any authz group applied under site, only course sites currently have sections and a mechanism of a) placing a macro and b) creating the groups/sections in the first place.
column64:
Permissions issues.

The current implementaiton uses the EntityProducer interface on the RWikiObjectService to generate a list of AuthZGroups on a RWikiEntity (Sakai Entity) that is then used in the AuthZGroupService to determine if he function/lock is granted to the user on the Wiki Page. In addition we layer page level permissions, although this may go with tighter integration with the Sakai Entity concepts (however these are legacy so I dont know their lifetime)

The main issue is this.

On the one hand, Resources appears to use a permissive inheritance model, if any of the parent permissions grants a lock, the lock is granted.

however

Sections are restrictive hence
Where a permission is expressed, that permissions and only that permission should be consulted and parent permissions must not be considered. This approach will make it possible for a subsite to be restricted to a smaller set of users.

Since we are trying to address sections that are more restrictive, I am proposing that we use a restrictive permissions inheritance model, ie permissions are not inherited, but if expressed, they are explicitly expressed completely.

I will need to check the implementaiton of AuthZGroups to make certain this is possible.

column1: [SAK-3727] Better support for Sections
column6:
Provide better support for sections with RWiki.

(Cut and paste from existing discussions)
Definition
We are not certain what this means and how sections actually work in other tools

  • We know
    o Sections Use AuthZ Groups for permissions
    o How are they exposed in a tool - are there links to a section - can the user select a section - is is annother tab on the top bar ?
  • Based on Sakai User Help (below)
    o 2 Issues
    + Access Control
    + How the tool reacts
  • Access Control
    o If we use a subsite to represent the section or group we can assign the section realm to the subsite, effectively giving control over that area to the members of the section/group
    o Requires Change Realm of Subsite (Cost Medium)
    o Problems
    + New pages from within the subsite are Ok, as they inherit the realm of the referncing page
    + We dont currently inforce that for referencing pages that outside the subsite, so the subsite could easilly become 'poluted' with other realms. - would need to fix this.
  • UI Issues
    o How does a TA setup the section/group subsites create section/group subsite wizard ? (Cost High)
    o How does a student know which subsite they can get to – the Index macro knowing more about access and membership ? Some special page ? A MySubsites/MyGroup macro ? (Cost Medium/High)
