column1: [SAK-8007] More flexible person names must be supported by Sakai
column6:
In Sakai's legacy user services, there are only two name fields for a person: "first name" and "last name". However, proper name ordering varies widely across cultures, and more name fields may be needed to support proper ordering.

Sakai applications typically show names in two ways.

1) As a greeting or other full name display. (This is LDAP's "cname" or "common name".) In English and most other European languages, the format is "GivenName [SecondGivenName] FamilyName". In Chinese, Hungarian, and Korean cultures, the format is "FamilyName GivenName".

2) As a sorting field. (For example, in a gradebook's list of students.) For an English name, the format would be "FamilyName, GivenName"; for a Chinese name, "FamilyName GivenName".

With middle names (AKA second given name), prepositions (AKA link names, or family name prefixes), and relationships (e.g., "Jr.", "III", "fils"), the rules across cultures become even more complicated.

Sakai needs to be able to properly display common-names and sorting-names for its users. Specifically, this requirement was entered to support Dutch names.

Use Cases:

  • A Dutch name such as "Victor van Dijk" needs to be alphabetized as "Dijk, Victor van".
  • A French name such as "Aimee de L'Aigle" needs to be alphabetized as "L'Aigle, Aimee de".
  • A Chinese name such as "Wong Kar-Wai" needs to be alphabetized as "Wong Kar-Wai".
  • A Welsh name such as "John Fitz Gerald" needs to be alphabetized as "Fitz Gerald, John".

Technical notes:

The Dutch and French cases above could be taken care of by adding a field to the existing Sakai user tables and forms. (A less user-friendly workaround with the current DB might be to put prepositional prefixes such as "van der" and "de" in the existing "first name" field.)

If required, the Chinese case could be taken care of by adding system-wide properties to configure the ordering of given and family names. However, this assumes that all users at a site follow the same naming conventions, which may not be true for all installations.

The distinction between "middle name" and "prepositional prefix" becomes more important when an honorific combines with the family name. For a Dutch name, it should be "Mr. Van Dijk" rather than "Mr. Dijk". In that case, it again becomes necessary to configure the orderings.

A simple approach used by some systems is to store "common name" and "sorting name" directly as separate fields.
column10: More flexible person names must be supported by Sakai
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44:
Victor, would using Middlename as you've described be a complete solution for Ducth names? Or, is just a best practice you've come to as a result of restrictive systems? For instance, I have a relative known as Peter Andrew von Knoop, where Andrew is truly a middlename (at least in the sense I'm used to in North America), but the von is something else. I've seen some systems that handle van, von, etc., as a "linkname" and separate from firstname, middlename, and lastname. In your example, it sounds like in this case alphabetization would follow:

[lastname], [firstname] [middlename] [linkname]
column48:
Peter, I wondered if I'd used the appropiate terminology. To use your example "Andrew" would be a 'second firstname' in Dutch and is only used with official cases like printed names on a degrees. The firstname is for daily usage and middlenames are not. Firstname is in this example the name that's being used by friends, co-workers etc. Like Peter in your example, if Peter is used by his surroundings.
Alphabetization would be:

[ lastname], [firstname] [linkname] -> 'Knoop, Peter van'
column52: Good, it sounds like we can kept this simple then: we can get by with supporting first, middle, and last names (unless someone else has use case otherwise?), and that the jist of the matter is to introduce configurable sorting in Sakai. Here in the US the need is for [middle=van] [last=Knoop], [first=Peter], wheres in Holland (and eslewhere?) one needs [last=Knoop], [first=Peter] [middle=van].
column56: Good! Excellent! That's what I was thinking. There is one more thing. If I look at the 'SAKAI_USER' table the column 'MIDDLE_NAME' needs to be added.
column60:
Name ordering issues like this are why we've been distinguishing between "sort name" and "display name" (equivalent to "greeting name") in our person-data service facades. (Another example: Chinese names which are ordered the same in both cases.) This is the sort of decision that should be handled framework-wide rather than leaving it up to the savvy of every application developer.

Behind the framework service scences, configurable sorting of FIRST_NAME, MIDDLE_NAME, LAST_NAME for each usage sounds like a good implementation approach.

I wonder if there are any existing Java libraries to handle this aspect of internationalization....
column64: The "salutation" use case ("Hello, Mr. Van Dijk") needsthe distinction between a "middle name" (= second given name) and a "link name", since Americans wouldn't say "Hello, Mr. Allen Poe". Luckily, I don't think any Sakai applications are that polite yet!
column132: I added some components to make the extent of the requirement clearer.
column143: Victor, as a temporary workaround until more flexible name support is available, could you handle your problem by putting "Victor van" in the first-name field and "Dijk" in the last-name field? It's counter-intuitive, but it seems as if it would end up generating the right alphabetization.
column150:
I tried to formalize the requirement but may have overgeneralized it. Here's Victor Maijer's original description:

In Dutch and other languages the use of 'Middlenames' is quite important and is being used different depending on the situation.
An example:
We have someone called 'Victor van Dijk'
The name could be defined as:
FIRSTNAME = 'Victor'
MIDDLENAME = 'van'
LASTNAME = 'Dijk'

Usage of this name would be as follows:
If you greet someone it would be:
'Hello [FIRSTNAME] [MIDDLENAME] [LASTNAME]' -> 'Hello Victor van Dijk'
or
'Hello Mr. [MIDDLENAME] [LASTNAME] -> 'Hello Mr. Van Dijk' (mind the use of the capitol 'V')

When we alphabetize, a list of students in a gradebook for example, it would be:
[LASTNAME], [FIRSTNAME] [MIDDLENAME]-> 'Dijk, Victor van'
and NOT like
[MIDDLENAME] [LASTNAME], [FIRSTNAME] -> 'Van Dijk, Victor'
This last example is how Blackboard handles 'Middlenames' and is the reason why out first instructors are walking away from Blackboard. It is not doable for them to administrate 300 students in a gradebook with faulty alphabetization.
column154: Reviewed by Worksite & Admin Tools.
column158: Thanks Ray for working this out! Your proposed workaround to put 'Victor van' in the first-name looks like a workable solution. I did a quick scan and it looks like either the 'user id' is used or the complete name (firstname lastname) is used.
column167:
As a side not in South Africa where Dutch and french names are not uncommon different ordering rules apply.

For instance Jan van der Merwe would be alphebatised under v rather than M as would be the case in Holland.
column171: Display names can be set using the DisplayAdvisorUDP interface. See: http://source.sakaiproject.org/release/2.4.0/javadoc/org/sakaiproject/user/api/DisplayAdvisorUDP.html

column1: [SAK-3724] WebDAV issues specific to mod_jk
column6:
Running the Litmus webdav compliance testkit (http://www.webdav.org/neon/litmus/, v0.10.5) highlights differences in behaviour between accessing WebDAV via an apache httpd + mod_jk frontend, and to tomcat directly.

Comparison of the litmus log output (from litmus -k) shows 3 locking tests which FAIL via mod_jk. 2 of these succeed when accessing tomcat directly, and 1 fails in a different way.

With mod_jk:

  • 8. refresh............... FAIL (LOCK refresh on `/dav/user/scm8/litmus/lockme': Could not read status line: connection timed out.)
    -35. refresh............... FAIL (LOCK refresh on `/dav/user/scm8/litmus/lockcoll/': Could not read status line: connection timed out.)
    -36. indirect_refresh...... FAIL (indirect refresh LOCK on /dav/user/scm8/litmus/lockcoll/ via /dav/user/scm8/litmus/lockcoll/lockme.txt: Could not read status line: connection timed out.)

Without mod_jk (direct to tomcat):

+ 8. refresh............... pass
+35. refresh............... pass
+36. indirect_refresh...... FAIL (indirect refresh LOCK on /dav/user/scm8/litmus/lockcoll/ via /dav/user/scm8/litmus/lockcoll/lockme.txt: Could not parse response: XML parse error at line 1: no element found)

column1: [SAK-3723] Multiple WebDAV protocol compliance issues
column6:
Running the Litmus WebDAV protocol compliance test suite (http://www.webdav.org/neon/litmus/) highlights numerous protocol compliance issues with WebDAV support.

To reproduce (on a *nix system):

1. Create a test webdav user, "davtest" password "dav123"
2. Login (to the portal) as the davtest user so the user's resources get created
3. Download, configure and install litmus. To enable SSL support, configure with:

./configure --with-ssl

4. Run make, and make install to install litmus.

5. Run test suite:

-----------
latte:/usr/local/src/litmus/litmus-0.10.5 # litmus http://nightly.cet.uct.ac.za:8080/dav/user/davtest/ davtest dav123 ->

running `basic':
0. init.................. pass
1. begin................. pass
2. options............... pass
3. put_get............... pass
4. put_get_utf8_segment.. pass
5. mkcol_over_plain...... FAIL (MKCOL on plain resource `/dav/user/davtest/litmus/res-%e2%82%ac' succeeded!)
6. delete................ pass
7. delete_null........... FAIL (DELETE nonexistent resource succeeded)
8. delete_fragment....... WARNING: DELETE removed collection resource with Request-URI including fragment; unsafe
...................... pass (with 1 warning)
9. mkcol................. pass
10. mkcol_again........... FAIL (MKCOL on existing collection succeeds)
11. delete_coll........... pass
12. mkcol_no_parent....... FAIL (MKCOL with missing intermediate succeeds)
13. mkcol_with_body....... FAIL (MKCOL with weird body must fail (RFC2518:8.3.1))
14. finish................ pass
<- summary for `basic': of 15 tests run: 10 passed, 5 failed. 66.7%
-> 1 warning was issued.

See debug.log for network/debug traces.
-----------

</D:response>

]

column154:
Webdav still fails compliance tests for props and locks. It is a popular service, that is costly to test against a range of browser types, versions and OS's. Therefore, would like to see as consistent with the protocol as possible.

Attached results against http://qa3-us.sakaiproject.org:8086 (Redhat Oracle 2.7.0 M1)
column158:
Props can probably be fixed, locks is tricker as would need cluster-wide locking.

I'd be interested to find out more about the real-world impact of props and locks, i.e. which clients use them, to inform a cost-benefit analysis of fixing them.

There is also a set of issues which don't show up on protocol compliance tests but do have real-world impact which is mainly to do with dealing with idiosyncracies of various DAV clients, e.g. the MacOS DS_Store issues, etc.
column167:
Several of the protocol failures appear to be attempts to make the service more robust, by permitting redundant operations. Are we sure fixing them would be a good idea?

As to the benefits, I test regularly with cadaver, OS X, Vista current SP and Windows 7. As far as I know, the protocol issues don't affect them. I have generally fixed any issues that break common clients, as long as they are fixable. In a few cases there were problems that weren't fixable, e.g. issues with older XP and Vista SP's, which would have required us to DAV-enable the whole URL space. There was also one minor version of OS X that had a problem that was practically unfixable. Fortunately the next version was OK.

Note that in order to get Vista/Windows 7 to work, I ended up faking setprops. It will claim that it did things that it didn't actually do. When I watched the transaction it was setting Windows-specific properties. Nothing seemed to break when they weren't actually saved, but rejecting the attempt did break things. Thus in order to do a real implementation we'd need to save arbitrary properties of files, not just map into the properties that we currently maintain. That's certainly possible.
column171:

column1: [SAK-3722] Load order problem with AddableSessionFactoryBean
column6: When using inheritance, base classes must be mapped before subclasses are. This means the mapping files must be processed in a certain order. If left alone, they are currently being processed in the order the components get loaded.
column10: Load order problem with AddableSessionFactoryBean
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44:
added a "sortOder" property to org.sakaiproject.springframework.orm.hibernate.impl.AdditionalHibernateMappingsImpl that will allow declared beans to control the order they are loaded in.

Hibernate has a problem when a base class and the derived class are in different mapping files. The base class must be mapped first. The load order of beans in components is indermined so if you are using hibernate inheritance and your beans are in different components, then be sure to use "sortOrder" on the bean with the base class in it:

<bean id="org.sakaiproject.springframework.orm.hibernate.AdditionalHibernateMappings.ospCommon"
class="org.sakaiproject.springframework.orm.hibernate.impl.AdditionalHibernateMappingsImpl">
<property name="mappingResources">
<list>
<value>org/theospi/portfolio/security/impl/simple/AuthorizationImpl.hbm.xml</value>
<value>org/theospi/portfolio/worksite/mgt/impl/SiteTool.hbm.xml</value>
<value>org/theospi/portfolio/guidance/model/Guidance.hbm.xml</value>
<value>org/theospi/portfolio/review/model/Review.hbm.xml</value>
</list>
</property>
<property name="sortOrder">
<value>1</value>
</property>
</bean>
column48: This should have been resolved in the 2.1.2 release. Unfortunately, there were not sufficiant QA resources to test this in that cycle. If you find this is still a problem, please reopen the ticket.

column1: [SAK-8014] Instructors should be able to disable a user's access to a site without removing the user from the site
column6:
An instructor may wish to disable a student's access to a site for an indefinite period of time because the student has not been participating as expected. It is possible to remove a student from a site when the student has been explicitly added as a site participant. However, for universities which integrate site memberships with official course registrations, the student might be re-added automatically.

Use Cases:

  • A student has been disruptive in a course site and needs to be blocked from the site. However, while the student remains on the official class roster, he continues to show up as a participant in the site. The instructor disables the student's access to the site without removing the student, and writes a message to explain why. When the student logs in and attempts to access the course site, he sees the message indicating why his access has been disabled.
  • After meeting with the disruptive student, the instructor re-enables the student's access to the course site.

column1: [SAK-7832] Users should be able to change their username and retain access to user data saved under the old username
column6:
When a user changes his username, the user no longer has access to data saved under the old username. Presently, this is a problem that is not easily solved because Sakai associates user data with the user's username. Therefore, to associate the data with a new username, the username would need to be changed for every tool that stores user data. Some of this data is stored in xml blobs, which is not easily accessible. To resolve this problem, Sakai can associate the user data with a randomly generated ID that is unique to the user rather than the user's username. This ID would be related to the user's username, which would allow the user's username to be changed in one table.

Requirements:
Sakai can associate user data with a randomly generated ID that is unique to the user
Sakai can associate the randomly generated ID with the user's username
Sakai administrators can change a user's username
User can still retain access to user data saved under the old username when logged in with the new username
column10: Users should be able to change their username and retain access to user data saved under the old username

column1: [SAK-3718] SAKAI_REALM SQL table definitions should include index
column6:
The legacy DbAuthzGroupService isAllowed(String userId, String lock, Collection realms) method is a database bottleneck when a large number of permissions have to be checked. For example, in a UC Berkeley course site with only 280 students, it took three and a half minutes for the "Drop Box" display to show up for instructors, and we found that virtually all that time was spent in that method.

Adding the following index to the SAKAI_REALM table decreased elapsed time to around 25 seconds:

CREATE INDEX SAKAI_REALM_IDKEY ON SAKAI_REALM
(
REALM_ID ASC,
REALM_KEY ASC
);

Given the magnitude of the performance improvement, this index should probably be defined in the "sakai_realm.sql" scripts for out-of-the-box Sakai as long as the legacy services continue in place.
column10: SAKAI_REALM SQL table definitions should include index
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44:
Checking with our CTools DBA, it's not clear that this index would have any effect on the query. We already have separate indexes on each of these fields, so I recommend careful study of this in an otherwise know-to-be-working Sakai installation before we add yet another index to our OOTB DDL.

I'm not questioning your results, Ray - but I know that Oracle is a finiky beasy (at best), and who knows what really turned the tide when you added that index. I'm further unsure of this because we are not seeing this sort of problem in other large Sakai installations (as far as I know).

I think it's worth a careful study.
column48:
That's interesting. The relevant comment from our DBA: "I found some examples of your query in yesterday's stats collection. I have created an additional index (realm_id,realm_key) on sakai_realm so that it doesn't have to visit the table."

I definitely established that our performance improvement was due to this "isAllowed" query:

statement = "select count(1) from SAKAI_REALM_RL_FN "
+ "where REALM_KEY in (select REALM_KEY from SAKAI_REALM where REALM_ID in "
+ buf.toString() + ")";
statement = statement + " and FUNCTION_KEY in (select FUNCTION_KEY from SAKAI_REALM_FUNCTION where FUNCTION_NAME = ?) "
+ "and (ROLE_KEY in " + "(select ROLE_KEY from SAKAI_REALM_RL_GR where ACTIVE = '1' and USER_ID = ? " +
// granted in any of the grant or role realms
"and REALM_KEY in (select REALM_KEY from SAKAI_REALM where REALM_ID in " + buf.toString() + ")) "
+ "or ROLE_KEY in (select ROLE_KEY from SAKAI_REALM_ROLE where ROLE_NAME = '" + ANON_ROLE + "') "
+ (auth ? "or ROLE_KEY in (select ROLE_KEY from SAKAI_REALM_ROLE where ROLE_NAME = '" + AUTH_ROLE + "') " : "")
+ ")";

As I understand it, the logic of adding the index is that only two columns of the SAKAI_REALM table are really needed, and this way the query gets to them right away. (Of course, the code could probably be restructured to be more efficient, but the index provides instant relief.)

If you don't have the index locally, it might be worth trying it out on a test copy of your DB (with a large course) and doing a before-and-after.
column52:
The Michigan DBAs were right to be skeptical about the value of the index-as-a-mini-table trick in this case. It turns out that our local comparison tests were contaminated by simultaneous changes being made without proper coordination. The large performance boost we saw was not due to adding the new DB index but to adding the line "cacheMinutes@org.sakaiproject.service.legacy.security.SecurityService = 5" to the test server's "sakai.properties".

Unfortunately, losing this magic bullet means that the performance of the Drop Box for a large class remains unacceptable. For a class with 258 students, the instructor has to wait 2 minutes for the Drop Box window to appear. This would be a blocker for UC Berkeley production deployment.

I'll get in touch again with Glenn and Lance, and, depending on what they say, open a new JIRA bug report to address the issue.

column1: [SAK-7896] Percentage based grading using categories
column6:
Allow instructors to set up their gradebooks based on percent weighted assigments, rather than (or as an alternative to) the current point-weighted assignments method.

Real life example from management class syllabus:

Students will be graded according the follwing formula:
Organization project report: 35%
Issue project report 35%
Student project presentation: 15%
Student overall Class participation: 15%

(end of example)

In the current GB the instructor would enter the numbers as points rather than percentages, but would then need to grade reports as a number between 0 and 35. In a percentage based system an instructor would grade all of the assignments from 0-100. The gradebook shoud then do the calculations based on the weights given.

This is the grading method that predominates at MIT.
column10: Percentage based grading using categories
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44: Weighted column needs can be catered to through formula (a.k.a "calculated") columns.
column48: Assigning to Luke for review.
column52: reassigning to myself to relieve Luke of some work.
column56: Ready for voting.
column60:
Here is another example from the trenches (at Michigan) on common weighted grading practices:

There are 7 assignments for the course:

4 Exams, each worth 14% of the final course grade
3 Reports, each worth 10% of the final course grade

So, together, they add up to 100% of the course grade.

Each assignment, however, is graded out of a hundred points. Students can
get a 100 on the first exam and will have completed 14% of the work.
column64:
This is also a big issue here at Marist College...

This is obviously a instructor "preference" issue meaning that mathematically either points or percentages results in the same final grade but I'm finding that some instructors have used the percentage method for 20+ years and changing that is not something they feel comfortable doing.

It would be great if we could provide instructor with this options.

Josh
column132: FWIW, this is very important here at the Univ of North Texas. Our instructors use this feature in WebCT Vista almost universally, and would require it before migrating to Sakai.

column1: [SAK-8066] Change the default name of "Tests & Quizzes" to "Assessments"
column6:
There is a desire to change the default name of SAMigo* from "Tests and Quizzes" to "Assessments" in the tool registration configuration file.

The main rationale for this name change is that SAMigo is often used for more generic assessment purposes in non-course sites like surveys. While the default name for any tool can be configured within Sakai, the gravity of a default name can be substantial (there is power in words and it is probably better when a default name meets the most, likely uses cases.

A little history on the name "Tests & Quizzes", so that it doesn't seem so arbitrary to detractors: before SAMigo was introduced into Sakai 1.5 it had been assumed that SAMigo would be called "Assessments". However, there was desire from some core schools to better distinguish its name and purpose from the existing "Assignments" tool, so it was "Tests & Quizzes" was adopted to better accomodate that desire.

  • For those who might not know the history of the name "Samigo", this the code/project name of what was originally intended to be the Sakai Assessment Manager (SAM). When it was discovered that a proprietary software already existed, (possibly Significance Analysis of Microarrays http://www-stat.stanford.edu/~tibs/SAM/) another name had to be coined.

Well, since the SAM project was the child of the Navigo project: SAM + igo = SAMigo
column10: Change the default name of "Tests & Quizzes" to "Assessments"
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44: I was actually just thinking abou this the other day and wishing it was called Assessments.
column48: At IU, we have renamed the tool to "Tests and Surveys" because "Tests and Quizzes" seemed to be a little redundant.
column52:
We'd like the default name to be different things in different sites. It would be ideal if the tool registration file could specify site-type-specific names, e.g. in course sites we'd call it Assessments, and in project sites we'd call it Surveys.

Samigo itself needs some tweaking to work well for Surveys, but that's another Requirement
column56:
I have been an advocate for this tool to have a different name, but I believe "assessments" is not a good replacement name. Please consider:

1. As a Collaboration and Learning Environment, many of us are deploying Sakai to support research, committees, and other activities that are not related to teaching and learning. SAMigo can be used to administer research surveys, but that important use will not be obvious in "worksites" if the tool name suggests a teaching purpose.

2. The term "assessment" has many, many different meanings. Some associate this term with ePortfolios while others see it as related to assignments. There are many views,and this name may just shift the confusion to a different area.

For there reasons, I don't believe the Current or proposed name are the best choice for a CLE. We deployed with a name of "Tests and Surveys" to meet #1. I am pleased to see this discussion.

-Brad
column60: I would go further than Stephen and say we would like to see the tool interface reflect a survey purpose in worksites and an assessment purpose in course sites. This should allow some simplification of the interface according to context specific purposes. That said, if the only offer on the table is a change to the name, I'm more inclined to go with Indiana's 'tests and surveys'.
column64:
I'd also like to see the default tool name changed. Tests and Quizzes doesn't capture surveying functionality, nor does it capture the tool's potential use for online tutorials or simulations.

We downplay TESTS in our own online environment and talk about quizzes. Tests seem to come with particular expectations that are difficult to meet with any online tool. Instructors want to somehow block students from using the internet while testing, to block them from any chance to save or print what they see on the screen, to stop them from simutaniously using email or IM, to never time students out, and to be utterly unsusceptible to network failure. Instructors do administer high-stakes tests in our current environment, but I believe they do so with the knowledge that a web-based testing comes with certain substantial caveats.

So, while I like the concreteness of Tests & Surveys, I am afraid of Tests. I suspect Quizzes & Surveys isn't accurate for schools that intend to use the tool for high-risk testing. Besides, I find that people don't always think of surveys and ballots the same way-- and that's another use that appears to be on the rise. That leaves me in the Assessment camp (even though I sympathize with Brad's comments about ePortfolio). In my experience, our researchers and staff haven't balked at the use of assessments as a teaching-only term.

Finally, I'd like to add to the discussion the notion that terms throughout the tool may need to be reassessed. With so many non-teaching uses of our own local tool, we have replaced Instructor and student with Manager and Respondent. I apologize that I haven't looked carefully at recent nightly builds, but I'm guessing that instructor and student show up hard-coded.

column64:
Thanks for the information, Beth. I figured this would be an easy one to knock off, but for some reason the region/locale side of the equation isn't working for me. (The language part is fine.) I'm specifying "-Duser.language=en -Duser.region=ZA" to Tomcat, I have "<supported-locale>en_ZA</supported-locale>" in my JSF configuration file, and I have a "Messages_en_ZA.properties" in the proper directory. And yet the "Messages_en.properties" strings keep stubbornly appearing instead....

I'm probably just doing something so blatantly dumb that my eyes are embarrassed to tell my brain about it. I'll be glad when I find out what it is, though.
column132:
In my tests, whether the supported-locale enables the "en_ZA" properties or not seems to depend (wrongly) on the ordering of the elements in the Faces config file. That is, this works:

<locale-config>
<default-locale>en</default-locale>
<supported-locale>en_ZA</supported-locale>
<supported-locale>en</supported-locale>
...

But this does not:

<locale-config>
<default-locale>en</default-locale>
<supported-locale>en</supported-locale>
<supported-locale>en_ZA</supported-locale>
...

Seems like a possible bug in MyFaces 1.0.9. I'll do some more research, but wanted to let the other JSF tool developers know what I've found.
column143:
It seems to be the intended behavior, and it's still in MyFaces 1.1.1. From the "JspViewHandlerImpl" code:

public Locale calculateLocale(FacesContext facesContext)
{
Iterator locales = facesContext.getExternalContext().getRequestLocales();
while (locales.hasNext())
{
Locale locale = (Locale)locales.next();
for (Iterator it = facesContext.getApplication().getSupportedLocales(); it.hasNext()
{
Locale supportLocale = (Locale)it.next();
// higher priority to a language match over an exact match
// that occures further down (see Jstl Reference 1.0 8.3.1)
if (locale.getLanguage().equals(supportLocale.getLanguage()) &&
(supportLocale.getCountry() == null ||
supportLocale.getCountry().length() == 0))
{
return supportLocale;

So ordering is meaningful here. Any regionalized locales should show up before their generic language locale, or they'll never be reached.
column150:

David, when you have such a file ready, feel free to assign a JIRA request on the Gradebook to officially incorporate it in Sakai.

column1: [SAK-7994] Configure Order of Items in Worksite's Lefthand Menu
column6:
The worksite instructor or maintainer should be able to re-order the worksite menu items, or the worksite's left-hand menu or toolbar, depending on what you like to call it. For example, if the instructor wants their course's menu to be ordered "Announcements, Dropbox, Discussion, Schedule, Assignments" they will be able to rearrange the order to fit that need.

Use Cases:

-instructors & maintainers have control over the "flow" of their course and are not restrained by the global menu properties

-worksites can have more variety in their appearance

-one could place the most commonly accessed tools in a worksite near the top

-tool order should start in a uniform order, such as alphabetical ( SAK-8107 Closed )
column10: Configure Order of Items in Worksite's Lefthand Menu
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44: Keeping a uniform order, however, would probably make it easier for folks working with multiple sites. For instance, students taking four or five courses would probably appreciate the tools always occuring in the same order – even if there are differences in the tool-sets used – in all their courses; having the Resource tool in the same general place each time means they can get to it more easily.
column48: I'd have to agree with Kim on this one. In 7+ years working with online learning, I've never heard of a student requesting the tools in a particular order. However, I've definitely had faculty members requesting this both with WebCT and Sakai. I guess, a new ticket could be created that requests the ability for any user to change the order of the menu items. This might solve the problem.
column52:
The Admin Sites tool has in the past provided a way for support staff to reorder and rename tools at a site. I believe the fact that instructors had to do this by request gave us a good balance of consistency and customization. Instructors who really needed it requested the changes and usually thought carefully about it first.

Unfortunately, this functionality has been buggy and broken, at least in our instance, for the last year.
column56: I don't see "mediated-functionality" as part of this requirement. I think ideally this could be an institutional setting: allow instructors to rename and reorder willy-nilly, only by request, or (as support policy) not at all.

column60:
OK looking at the code (apologies to non-technical people...) here's the regular expression that deals with lists:

(^[
p

{Space}](-#*|-#*[iIaA1ghHkKj]\\.)[
p{Space}

]([^\r\n])[\r\n]*)+

this is basically read as:

Newline followed by spaces. Then some list marker followed by at least one space. Content followed by any number of new lines.

The hack solution is to put a slash-space on the separator line.

i.e.

  • list 1
  • list 1
    \
    *list 2
    *list 2

(note the space after the slash!)

column1: [SAK-3710] inactive exam visible in student view - returns security error
column6:
Although an assessment IS retracted, it is still visible and accessible to students despite the fact that...

a) the due date has passed
b) it was set to "late submissions will not be accepted"

Upon further investigation, we found that inactive assessments are still visible/accessible to students who had clicked "save and continue" but had not submitted them. The problem with that since a link is there, they attempt to submit for grading, and they get a security java error. I am not sure if this is due to the fact that the due date has passed and late submissions are not allowed, or because the test is inactive and they should not be able to submit.

      • In either case, an inactive exam should not be visible/accessible to students who had saved some answers. The security java error is causing a lot of stress to students. Since they can access the exam, they assume that they can still submit it. It seems that when an exam is retracted, all instances should be removed from the student view.
      • Also, if a retracted exam is set to "late submissions will be accepted but will be tagged late during grades" allows students to submit! I don't know if this is by design or whether we are not understanding how the software works, but if an assessment is retracted, it should not be visible by any students (partially saved responses or submitted).

Is this proper behavior? We understood that retracted assessments are not visible/accessible to students. No?
column10: inactive exam visible in student view - returns security error
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44: Vivie, if a student hit 'save and exit' can he/she still see the assessment in the list? I tested it and I was not able to see it. So it seems the problem is only when the student clicked on 'save and continue' and waited till the retract date has been reached, right?
column48:
I have spent all day doing extensive testing, and I am more confused than when I started....

Conditions:

  • Insructor has selected "Submissions will not be accepted after DUE date."
  • Instructor retracts exam early (before due date)
  • At least one student has taken the exam.

--> user A selects answers and clicks on "save and continue" and leaves the process half-way.
--> user B selects no answers whatsoever and clicks on "save and continue" and goes thru the whole thing or leave half-way.
--> user C completes the whole test and clicks on "save and exit" but does not submit for grading.

The software worked properly and did NOT display retracted assessments for either of the above users.

However, retracted assessments were visible/accessible to my test user D who had NEVER accessed them. The assessments were available to her in the "Take an Assessment" list, although they were past due AND inactivated. The due date was listed in red. The software let her go through the test, but when she clicked on submit for grading, she get:

"There was a SECURITY ERROR submitting this assessment. Please contact your system administrator for more information. Error details: java.lang.IllegalAccessException: The agent has not successfully set the JavaScript flag."

This aligns with reports from students and faculty at Foothill at our help desk.

------------------------------------------------------------------------
I took a couple of hours break and returned to testing to write it up with clarity for you. For the life of me, I now cannot replicate the above! I don't understand what's going on - whethere there was another condition in the mix that I am forgetting or whether the behavior is elusive and inconsistent. I certainly got the error earlier today and at the office with students! I am at a loss!

Other questions:
--------------------

1) User goes through test and "submits for grading." The test is later retracted by the instructor (before due date), yet the student is able to see the retracted accessment. Is this proper behavior? (Users who did NOT submit the retracted exam, they do not see it. I understood this to be correct behavior)

2) If instructors have selected that "submissions will be accepted late but will be tagged during grading," BUT they retracted the test early (prior to the due date) due to issues with the test, should the software let students take the assessment? Sure, the test is set to accept late submissions, but after it's inactive, shouldn't it no longer be visible? Aren't retracted exams not meant to be visible by any students?

Cause of issues for our users:
--------------------------------------------
The confusion with the above is the fact that faculty are using the retract feature in two ways - to make a test invisible to students after it's taken AND to remove weak exams (discovered after publication) from the active list since no delete option is available in Samigo. The inability to delete (or remove) exams is frustrating for our instructors. There seems to be a need for "trashing" exams (saved in a list) in addtion to retracting good, completed tests. The ability to remove an inactive exam from the gradebook and change the settings of an exam from the inactive list helps (used as a workaround), but the fact that some students can access retracted exams and get security java errors is causing problems.

Not sure if this is the right place for these questions... Let me know if there is a better place. Thanks.
column52: Vivie, do you still see this problem in 2.1.1?
column56: No. This is fixed in 2.1.1.. Thank you all VERY much! Please close.
column60: This was fixed as part of delivery refactoring in 2.1.1.

column52: the Score field is an inputText field so I removed the rounding. Doing this allows us to use the most accurate values for calculation. For example, if a question is worth 3.33333 but iwe round it up to 3.33 for display in this inputText field, when the user hits 'update' button, the calculation will be done based on 3.33 , not 3.33333 .thus it will not be accurate anymore.

column1: [SAK-8113] Paging description for List Navigator needs to better explain what to do at boundaries
column6:
This was implemented in Sakai in r5861 (post-2.1.1). So this requirement is really just for the New Tools now; and, if we are going to use the Style Guide or something similar going forward, then it should include a description of this aspect of the paging process.

Original Description:
For the List Navigator a better description of what should happen as one pages through a list and hits a boundary is needed. The current beahvior in most circumstances is that when you are viewing 20 items at a time from a 33 item list Next will move you from viewing 1-20 to viewing 14-33. Preference has been expressed for it behaving otherwise and making the boundaries firm so you are not seeing items on multiple pages; view 1-20 and then view 21-33. No preference has been expressed yet for keeping it the way it currently works.

This requirement should apply to both paging JSF widget and the style guide definition.
column10: Paging description for List Navigator needs to better explain what to do at boundaries
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44:
The proposed solution is appropriate - it matches the design patter seen in webmail applications.

This bug has a major dependancy on another unstated bug. There is currently no way to approve and make changes to the sakai style guide. it is a dead document, with no owner. It is owned by the Sakai UI DG, but there is no working group working on it.

Until it is resolved who approves changes to the style guide, who makes those changes and how those changes are made (continue updating a Word document or publish more openly?), this bug can't be resolved.

column1: [SAK-3705] Login may confuse multiple usage sessions and lead to incorrect presence disply
column6:
It has come to our (CTools at University of Michigan) attention that the UUID generator in Sakai may not be doing quite what we need it to be doing.

Recently we had many support reports about strange user names showing up in the presence of their sites. This turned out to be presence displays from the activity of legitimate users, but users who have had their login usage session confused with some other user, so the name shows incorrectly.

When this occurs, there are only two real problems. One is that the presence display is wrong, which is disturbing to the users. The other is that the usage events of more than one session become tangled up in the database. While the user is logged in, any action they take is attributed to their user id (other than for the usage events), and permissions are properly figured based on their real user id.

The problem can be seen in the catalina.out logs with a warning like this:

WARN: Sql.dbWrite(): sql: insert into SAKAI_SESSION (SESSION_ID,SESSION_SERVER,SESSION_USER,SESSION_IP,SESSION_USER_AGENT,SESSION_START,SESSION_END) values (?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?) binds: 4071daa6-8acb-4650-8064-b6930546748a kungpao-1138270342004 userid 141.211.253.192 Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.7.2) Gecko/20040804 Netscape/7.2 (ax) 20060126184426137 20060126184426137 java.sql.SQLException: ORA-00001: unique constraint (CTOOLS_USER.CHEF_SESSION_PK) violated
(2006-01-26 13:44:26,148 TP-Processor147_org.sakaiproject.component.framework.sql.BasicSqlService)
WARN: .addSession(): dbWrite failed (2006-01-26 13:44:26,149 TP-Processor147_org.sakaiproject.component.adaptor.UsageSessionServiceAdaptor)

This says that the usage session record cannot be added because the id is in use (btw, our system database is so old it has something called a CHEF_SESSION_PK - yours will probably have something more sakai-like).

The id is created just before this call by the IdManager. The failure of the insert leads me to believe that the id generated has been generated before.

The IdManager's API contract is to give us a new id that has never been generated before in this Sakai. This means it has to also be unique across the Sakai cluster. At one point we used a database sequence to implement this contract. Now we use the Apache Commons ID project's code to generate a type 4 UUID.

The type 4 is a random number. There is no real guarantee that this will meet the API contract of uniqueness across the app servers over all time. On the other hand, experience has shown that it works "pretty well".

Many of the ids generated are used as table keys, so we will get "unique constraint" sort of errors from the db if the id is repeated, ONLY if the id is repeated in the same table. So we might be getting more failures of this API contract that we don't notice and don't really hurt us.

We studied our logs for this warning, and since last september, have seen exactly 391 occurrences; 1 on one app server, 390 on another (we were running 12 at the time), and all within a 2 day period late in January of this year. That, to me, is a very strange occurrence pattern (and leaves me wondering if there's some other factor involved in this).

I want to improve error handling for at least this one case in login. The code detects that the new usage session record was not able to be added, then ignores the problem and continues on assuming that this usage session id is good. This is what leads to the mixup in the event records and presence. If the usage session record insert fails, we can send the error back to the user (something like "unable to login, please try again").

While this is just one small case where the id generator's failure causes problems, it's a scary one for end users and messes up event tracking so I think it's worth fixing. It does raise the large issue of error handling throughout Sakai - this is a big nasty issue, and many folks have noticed that we don't do a great job of handling strange errors (too many places we just catch everything, maybe log it, and go on).
column10: Login may confuse multiple usage sessions and lead to incorrect presence disply
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44: I did not see the Warn: described in any of the nightly2 logs. Closing and will watch for it on our servers when we move to 2.1.2.

column1: [SAK-3704] IdManager component based on type 4 UUID generator fails to generate unique ids
column6:
It has come to our (CTools at University of Michigan) attention that the UUID generator in Sakai may not be doing quite what we need it to be doing.

Recently we had many support reports about strange user names showing up in the presence of their sites. This turned out to be presence displays from the activity of legitimate users, but users who have had their login usage session confused with some other user, so the name shows incorrectly.

When this occurs, there are only two real problems. One is that the presence display is wrong, which is disturbing to the users. The other is that the usage events of more than one session become tangled up in the database. While the user is logged in, any action they take is attributed to their user id (other than for the usage events), and permissions are properly figured based on their real user id.

The problem can be seen in the catalina.out logs with a warning like this:

WARN: Sql.dbWrite(): sql: insert into SAKAI_SESSION (SESSION_ID,SESSION_SERVER,SESSION_USER,SESSION_IP,SESSION_USER_AGENT,SESSION_START,SESSION_END) values (?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?) binds: 4071daa6-8acb-4650-8064-b6930546748a kungpao-1138270342004 userid 141.211.253.192 Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.7.2) Gecko/20040804 Netscape/7.2 (ax) 20060126184426137 20060126184426137 java.sql.SQLException: ORA-00001: unique constraint (CTOOLS_USER.CHEF_SESSION_PK) violated
(2006-01-26 13:44:26,148 TP-Processor147_org.sakaiproject.component.framework.sql.BasicSqlService)
WARN: .addSession(): dbWrite failed (2006-01-26 13:44:26,149 TP-Processor147_org.sakaiproject.component.adaptor.UsageSessionServiceAdaptor)

This says that the usage session record cannot be added because the id is in use (btw, our system database is so old it has something called a CHEF_SESSION_PK - yours will probably have something more sakai-like).

The id is created just before this call by the IdManager. The failure of the insert leads me to believe that the id generated has been generated before.

The IdManager's API contract is to give us a new id that has never been generated before in this Sakai. This means it has to also be unique across the Sakai cluster. At one point we used a database sequence to implement this contract. Now we use the Apache Commons ID project's code to generate a type 4 UUID.

The type 4 is a random number. There is no real guarantee that this will meet the API contract of uniqueness across the app servers over all time. On the other hand, experience has shown that it works "pretty well".

Many of the ids generated are used as table keys, so we will get "unique constraint" sort of errors from the db if the id is repeated, ONLY if the id is repeated in the same table. So we might be getting more failures of this API contract that we don't notice and don't really hurt us.

We studied our logs for this warning, and since last september, have seen exactly 391 occurrences; 1 on one app server, 390 on another (we were running 12 at the time), and all within a 2 day period late in January of this year. That, to me, is a very strange occurrence pattern (and leaves me wondering if there's some other factor involved in this).

I see a few possible actions to take here. We can change the IdManager implementation. Apache Commons ID has 2 other standard UUID generator types, each more complex to setup than the last, but all staying within the app server. We could also ressurrect the database sequence based id generator which really has a guarantee of being unique across the app servers over all time (at least until the db is reset), but is more expensive as it touched the db for each id. Since the IdManager is a component, we could have a few different implementations in the code base that we Sakai installers can choose from.

column44: Fixed and cleanup calMode
column48:
Adding Huong's explanation:

Hi Margaret -
There was a bug on calMode where it does not include mode where score is non decimal points.
such as:
Example 1: scores are 1.0,2.2,3.3,1.0, 2.2
mode should return 1,0, 2.2
Example 2: scores: 1.2,3.4,3.4,1.2,4.5
mode should return 1.2,3.4
But the result before was only 2.2 for example 1 and correct for example 2
Now, it should be correct in both cases

This is very easy to test in program rather than by taking the test. But if you like you can test it for about few students, and adjust their score in the way you wanted then, view histogram and see the mode show up right. By the way, the mode is the the most common number happens.

I did test in my program by giving list of scores, and it printed out correctly. Any more questions, please let me know.
column52:

There is still a problem when all the scores are unique, but I'll open a separate bug on that. Linking to tracking bug to wait for stable.

column1: [SAK-7849] Configurable Permissions in Resources
column6:
The instructor or maintainer of a worksite will have the ability to set permissions for individual folders and files within resources. For example, an instructor could restrict (hide) a folder in Resources until he is ready to make it available to students. The instructor would do:
-Resources
-Click "Folder Permissions" next to the desired sub folder
-Unclick the checkbox next to Student and under "read" (currently this is checked by default and cannot be altered when read is allowed at the site level)

The current design of requiring instructors to turn off read permissions at the site level to prevent read access to subfolders is undesirable as it is more likely that instructors will want to turn off access to individual folders & files while leaving the majority of documents as read access.

column1: [SAK-3700] docs/sakai.properties cleanup
column6:
docs/sakai.properties is missing a few important pieces, even upon casual review. It needs to be gone over more carefully and cleaned up. Since many implementers use docs/sakai.properties as their reference, this is important for the release.

There should be a couple stages to this fix.

1) docs/sakai.properties must be verified to contain at least all the appropriate settings for DB configuration, and these can presumably be copied from the kernel's sakai.properties.

2) docs/sakai.properties needs to be brought in line with docs/architecture/sakai_properties.doc. Too many pieces of each do not correspond.

column1: [SAK-4866] Private Messages / Message not Received when Replying to Message you Sent and Including Additional Recipient
column6:
Here are the steps to reproduce the problem.

1. As an Instructor, compose a message and select 'Instructor Role' from the To field.
2. Fill in any required fields and click Send.
3. In your Received folder, select the message you just sent and click Reply to Message.
4. Select an additional recipient from the To field (e.g., an Individual)
5. Fill in any required fields and click Send.

The recipient you selected receives the message, but you do not. I've verified that this problem exists in production and on Nightly 2 HSQL. Please let me know if you need any additional information.

column1: [SAK-7990] User Profile Tool
column6:
In the User Profile Tool, each Sakai user could upload:
-an image of themselves
-information about themselves

This tool would be linked with the "Users Present" feature currently in Sakai. Each name in the "Users Present" area would be clickable by other worksite users. When a name is clicked it would open the user profile in a separate window. The user's image & text introduction about themselves would be displayed.

This type of tool would be beneficial as it would assist in the formation of an online community.
column10: User Profile Tool
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44:
There seem to be two distinct parts to this requirement.

1) A user should be able to upload their picture directly in the Profile tool.

2) A person's Profile should be directly linked from the person's ID in the Presence tool (assuming that the current user is authorized to view the person's profile data).

These two parts have separate requirements elsewhere in JIRA, and so I'm closing this one.

Kim, if I've missed something, please re-open this and assign it to me.
column48: Closed instead of resolved

column1: [SAK-3699] Schdule - event types are not localizable
column6:
The localization of event types is broken in several key areas:

1) The drop downs in new.vm and revise.vm checked for the event type of the curent event so that the corret type is selected by default. The code to check the type is hard coded #elseif ($event.getType()=="Activity") but the value of the field is set to the language setting: <option selected="selected">$tlang.getString("del.computer")</option>

2) in viewActivity.vm the code to display the event type checkes for a hard coded value to diplay the correct icon. If the instalation is localized the event type is not diplyed as the value is not returned.

Solution: the value of the drop down should be set:
<option selected="selected" value="computer">$tlang.getString("del.computer")</option> so that event types get displayed regardles of the end users language preference.
column10: Schdule - event types are not localizable

column1: [SAK-7963] worksite statistics
column6:
Using a worksite statistics tool, a maintainer, instructor or admin could determine who has accessed the worksite and what was accessed for a specified time period. The statistics would be reported by the tool in the forms of tabular data as well as graphical bar charts.

The worksite statistics tool would consist of appropriate menus (checkboxes, calendar selection, pull-down menus) that would allow the instructor to specify which statistics to query, such as:

Start Date
End Date
Users (individual, multiple selections, or all)
Area (individual, multiple selections, or all)

Areas that would be queried for statistics would include:
Announcements
Assignments
Chat Room
Discussion Board
Gradebook
Presentation
Resources
Schedule
Syllabus
Test & Quizzes
Web Content

column1: [SAK-4509] What's New? tool (Recent Activity) [Formerly REQ-87]
column6:
When any user (regardless of type) accesses a worksite, they will have access to a tool which summarizes worksite activity and updates since their last login. This new tool will list to the user any changes (new or updates) in the following areas:
-announcements
-assignments
-chat
-dropbox
-email archive
-presentation
-resources
-schedule
-syllabus
-test & quizzes
-web content
-newly added users
-etc.

column1: [SAK-8173] The Drop Box tool should work better with course sections
column6:
The Drop Box should be changed to give instructors and TAs assigned to individual sections an easier and more organized way to work with students in sections.

The original requirement description suggested creating Drop Box section folders. When an instructor creates sections in his course site, a Drop Box folder hierarchy would be based on those sections.

There are some possible issues with that approach, however.

1) A student can be in more than one section, which means the Drop Box would appear multiple times.
2) Because the Drop Box and Resource "Title" sorts only happen within folders, it would become impossible for the instructor to quickly access the drop box for a single student without also knowing what sections the student was in.
3) A TA still sees all the drop boxes for students who aren't in the TA's assigned sections.

A different approach to making the Drop Box section aware would be to support filtering by section name (e.g., with a drop-down menu showing the names of all sections that the instructor or TA has access to) and only show TAs sections which are assigned to them.

Use Cases:

  • An instructor creates Lab 1 and Lab 2 sections. The course site's Drop Box then displays the following folder tree:

folder SMPL 001 001 W06 dropbox
subfolder Lab 1
subfolder Bob Jones
subfolder Ann Smith
subfolder Lab 2
subfolder Joe Jackson
subfolder Kate Klein

  • An instructor goes to the Drop Box and sees folders for all students. To focus on the students in Lab 2, she selects "Lab 2" from the sections menu.
  • A TA who is assigned to the Lab 2 section goes to the Drop Box and sees folders only for students in the Lab 2 section.

column1: [SAK-3681] Assignments / Grades aren't Transferring to GB for Assignments Posted to GB with Duplicate Assignment in GB
column6:
Good morning! We are evaluating the grading feature in the assignments tool because we would like to add this feature into our production environment. While evaulating, one of our customers asked what would happen if an instructor created an assignment in the Gradebook with the name of 'Homework 1' and then created an Assignment in the Assignments tool called 'Homework 1' and chose to post it to the gradebook. I tried this out on nightly2 and it seems like this is currently a bug because when I returned a grade for this assignment, the grade does not show up in the gradebook.

I checked out Samigo to see how they handle this problem and unfortunately, they don't. If there is an assignment in the gradebook with the same name as a quiz in Samigo, the user receives an error when trying to publish a quiz that tells them to contact their local help desk for assistance.

I'd like to propose a couple of options for resolving this problem that wouldn't result in an error message to the user.

1) We could require the user to first create an assignment in the gradebook and then from the Assignments tool, the user could pick the GB Assignment with which he/she wished to associate his/her Assignment in the Assignments tool from a dropdown list. This would replace the 'Add to Gradebook' checkbox. It would instead be labeled 'Choose Gradebook Assignment'
2) We could create the assignment, but append something to the end to make the name different from the existing assignment because the gradebook does not allow duplicates. I'm not sure of the proper designation, maybe a '(1)' or something to that effect.

Either of these solutions would ensure that duplicating the name of an assignment would not result in an error message to the user. Once we decide on a solution, I'll submit a bug to Samigo to ensure that it behaves in the same manner. Thanks!

In the instance when an assignment with the same name has been created in the gradebook prior to the instructor creating the assignment in the assignments tool, we need another solution. Solution 1 above would resolve both situations.

column1: [SAK-7878] Contact/Help tool that records user state
column6:
An online help form that captures the user system info as well as the referring URL or siteID.

  • referring URL or site ID
  • Platform and OS
  • connection or ISP
  • Browser and version
  • username
  • firewall info
  • description of problem/issue/question

Ideally, this form would capture information about what tool the user is currently in, what site they are in, any information that can be pulled from the browser about their system, and anything that might help troubleshoot the problem they are having.

The email address where the help request is sent should be configurable.

Use Case:
A user encounters a problem while using sakai. They click on the "request assistance" link at the top (or some other name) and a pop up window appears. The window contains information about the user and what they were doing before they clicked on the help link. They fill in a description of their problem or question and then click a button to send this to a helpdesk email address.

column1: [SAK-8044] Incorporate Gradebook with graded assignments
column6:
When an instructor or TA creates a new graded assignment using the Assignment tool, the instructor/TA should have the ability to automatically create a gradebook column that corresponds to that assignment. For example, a checkbox such as "Create corresponding gradebook column" could be added to the other options " Add due date to schedule", "Announce the open date", & "Add honor pledge". It may be more desirable to have the column automatically created by default and to make the checkbox "Do NOT add column to the gradebook" since most instructors/TAs would probably want the column created by default. The new gradebook column should be created with the appropriate title, point value & due date.

Additionally, the new column in the gradebook should indicate to the instructor which students have submitted which assignments and which assignments still require grading through some sort of iconography. The instructor can either grade the assignments through the Assignments tool or through the gradebook view.

When a student submits the file for review to the instructor/TA, the gradebook view will reflect this status change through some kind of icon.

When the instructor/TA grades the item, the grade will be shown in both the Assignments and Gradebook areas. When the instructor/TA updates the grade, the grade will be updated in both the Assignments and Gradebook areas.

column1: [SAK-3677] Dates are incorrectly formated in regards to Daylight Savings Time (e.g. EST/EDT or GMT/BST)
column6: Date are incorrectly formated (apparently in all Schedule pages), displaying "WEST" on any locale. In our case, it should be displaying like "9:00 am - 1:00 pm GMT" - or even simpler: "9:00 am - 1:00 pm".
column10: Dates are incorrectly formated in regards to Daylight Savings Time (e.g. EST/EDT or GMT/BST)
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44:
Nuno,
the WEST is what comes up when the time zone for your area is set as the preference. So for example, if I pick my time zone, I get EDT for Eastern Daylight Time. If I pick London, I get a timezone designation of BST. Schedule gets the designator from some international time zone service.

Beth - is there another set of designators we could/should use?
column48:
Beth,
My apologies as I found a way to change locale in Preferences/Locale and could verify that the label actually changed for different time zones.
We are used to see GMT for both London or Lisbon time zone instead of WEST and BST, but, as I could comprove on the site below, you are using the correct designation despite of the fact that we never used here so, my (big) apologies for this.

http://wwp.greenwichmeantime.com/time-zone/

Sorry,
Nuno.
column52:
The timezone designation comes from the standard Java TimeZone class (http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/api/java/util/TimeZone.html), which uses a 3 or 4 character designation for it's shorter representation. WEST is used for Portugal on daylight savings time, while WET is the designation that probably should be displayed (according to http://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/timezone.html?n=133). It looks like your server thinks it's on daylight savings time, for some reason, but the designation is otherwise correct, as far as I can tell (my linux box reports the timezone as 'WET' when I change /etc/localtime to Portugal).

You could change your TimeZone preferences to report GMT.
column56:
We're reopening this as Schedule is picking the wrong 3-letter string out of the time designator when it displays the zone. The time zone is currently displayed as BST instead of GMT.

(i.e. times are labelled as British Summer Time, which is one hour ahead of GMT)

We believe that the auto-switching timezone is correct (the times are calculated correctly) but the time zone string displayed on screen is wrong. The only way to get GMT to appear is to change your personal timezone to something that forces GMT to appear, but that is impractical for all users to do!
column60: Harriet, what is the Time Zone set to in your Preferences?
column64: Also, what is the time zone set to on your server (if this is a linux box, type "date" at the command line)?
column132:
Most people are by default set to "Europe/London" in their preferences in our Sakai system and that applies to the situation that Harriet describes.

The Linux box running Sakai is currently in GMT (as per 'date') but the locale should be set such that it will automatically switch back and forth to BST on the appropriate days each year.

Note that in the UK GMT strictly means the time we use in winter and is basically exactly the same as UTC. When we go into daylight savings time (a term we don't realy use in the UK) we move into BST (British Summer Time) which is not GMT. Continuing to display BST makes people assume that the clock is stuck in its summer position and that somebody has forgotten to put it back an hour in the Autumn (Fall).

The equivalent problem in the US would be to display something like "EDT" all year round, instead of showing "EST" in the winter.
column143: Beth, I played around with this a bit further too, resting the clock and local at the server level, in addition to playing with Preferences. It appears that whenever you are in daylight or non-daylight savings time for the timezone you've chosen, then the Schedule displays events that should have the other time with the wrong timezone (e.g., EDT vs. EST). There are additinal examples of how this manifests itself in the issues linked as duplicates.
column150:
Upgrading this since it affects almost all international users and fixing the component
Can someone please look at this issue more closely, it is critical for those of us who are not in the US since students are notified of the incorrect times in messages and interfaces in Sakai which makes the schedule (calendar) and anything else affected by this effectively useless to us
column154:
Problem (finally) tracked down and fixed. The correct timezone/daylight-savings status is now displayed in Schedule tool.

QA Instructions:
1) Verify timezone displayed in schedule tool (above "Previous Week", "Today", "Next Week" buttons) is correct (e.g. EST)
2) Change the server's date to a summer month, for example, try this on a linux server (yymmdd)"
$ sudo date -s 080731 +%D
3) Verify timezone is now displayed for daylight savings (e.g. EDT).
4) Restore correct time on server!
column158: This is a simple change to a nagging problem – please merge to 2.5.x.
column167: merged into 2-5-x with r40571
column171:
Verified this on QA1 UK server sakai_2-5-0_RC_02a. Login with my Id's Changed TimeZone to NewYork Time on Preferences. Then created shedule event and saved changes. The time didn't change according to EDT it remain in EST. Not sure why. See screen shot
Thank you,
column181: Renuka, we are currently not on Daylight Savings time in the Eastern US, so you should expect to see EST (Eastern Standard Time) rather than EDT (Easter Daylight Time.) So perhaps you've verified that this issue has been fixed and is ready to be closed?
column185:
Hi Peter I understand that we are on EST now. Some one from QA1 UK server volunteered to force the time to reflect EDT this morning.
Thank you,
column189: Renuka, check your screenshot. It shows today's date, 29-Feb-2008, as the date you created your event for. Today occurs during standard time, not daylight time, so it is correct. I'm not sure what else you're expecting to see here?
column193:
Peter, The QA team forced to change the time on the server to show Daylight savings time. I am expecting to see EDT after the time instead of EST. See comments above from "Beth Krkschner" test 2 and 3.
Probably that might explain what I am trying to test and see results. Thank you.
column197:
Renuka, February 29th will ALWAYS be standard time if your time zone preference is set for New York...

I'm not sure what you're trying to test here. This issue's summary talks about the "WEST" issue, which certainly seems to be resolved. Perhaps you could update the summary to reflect what additional things you're attempting to test here.
column201: Currently the US is in daylight savings time, while Europe is not (due to the US moving it's DST early). Looking at the QA Servers, I notice the US QA servers correctly display EDT, and the European servers (e.g. qa1-nl) correctly displays CET. Perhaps the attempt to reset the server time was not done correctly? In any case, if there is still a problem, can you reproduce it on one of the QA servers – we have a window in time (until March 30th) where no sysadmin changes are needed to test this.
column205:
Beth, I can't speak to all the comments above, but for the issue of displaying the correct time zone for an event – which is what I think this issue end up being here – there still seems to be a problem. The interface is always displaying the current timezone of the current server time, regardless of when the event in question falls; it might fall on a day when that timezone happens to be in daylight savings time or it might not, when "today" is in daylight savings time or not. When the event's daylight status is different then the current time, then it does appear to be calculating the correct time to display, it's just not displaying the right timezone.

Create an event for 11AM today, 11 March 2008. My timezone and QA3's are set to America/Detroit, and this zone is currently on daylight time (i.e., EDT, not EST, should be displayed for the event.) The event correctly displays as 11:00AM EDT.

If you change your timezone to various settings you also correctly see:

Europe/London 3:00PM GMT (not on daylight time on 11 March)
Europe/Amsterdam 4:00PM CET (not on daylight time on 11 March)
America/Phoenix 8:00AM MST (not on daylight time on 11 March)

This is also what was observed prior to the switch to daylights savings time in the Eastern time zone, for an event on 29 February (also created on 29 February), including the event being correctly displayed as EST and the other timezones. Good so far.

Create an event today for 11AM on 4 March 2008. This event is for a time prior to daylight time taking effect in the Eastern timezone, so it is an event for 11AM EST. The current date when this event is being crated is11 March 2008, which is on Daylight time, but that shouldn't matter, as the event is being created for a date on which the Eastern timezone is still on standard time.

When I go to add the event, the timezone displayed is EDT and doesn't change to EST when I switch the date to 4 March 2008. This is one part of the problem. There does not appear to be code in the current interface, however, to support the dynamic changing of the timezone, so that needs to be addressed.

After I save the event, it is correctly displayed in the 11:00AM slot in the week view. If I view the event's details, however, it reports that it is set for 11:00 am EDT, which again is incorrect, it should say 11:00 am EST. If I change my timezone preference, and review the details for this event, then the time displayed is correct across timezones for this 4 March event, as is the timezone:

Europe/London 4:00PM GMT (not on daylight time on 4 March)
Europe/Amsterdam 5:00PM CET (not on daylight time on 4 March)
America/Phoenix 9:00AM MST (not on daylight time on 4 March)

Note that for all the above timezones, they are are still on standard time. I expect, however, that if you did this same experiment in June (or set the server clock to June), and created an event for 4 March, then you would be seeing the correct time for the event still, but with the wrong timezone for London and Amsterdam (Phoenix never goes on daylight time.)

If I go ahead today and create an 11:00AM event for 11 June 2008, then it correctly displays as 11:00 am EDT, daylight time is in effect on 11 June 2008. If I switch my timezone preference, the time is still displayed correctly, however, the timezones that will be on daylight that day (but on standard now) are displayed incorrectly (London and Amsterdam):

Europe/London 4:00PM GMT (on daylight time on 11 June)
Europe/Amsterdam 5:00PM CET (on daylight time on 11 June)
America/Phoenix 8:00AM MST (not on daylight time on 11 June)

Hope that all makes sense...
column209: Verified this for day light savings time, time displayed is correct. When I try to set the event duration to one hour from 9:00 to 11:00 A.M. then open an event to view , the time displayed as 9:00 to 10:59 A.M. Not sure why it is not rounding to '0'. I also noticed the event I created on Feb 29th changed to EDT. Depending on the time and month it is created it should remain same after time changes.

column1: [SAK-7830] Reordering of Resource Items
column6:
The current resources tool allows for a variety of ways to sort resources, but does not give the instructor the option to set a default ordering of those resources. This occasionally forces faculty to rename their resources in manipulative ways simply to have the arrangement of folders and files happen in the way they wish.

Use cases:

  • An instructor sets a "default" ordering for a site's resources, which need not adhere to any sorting algorithm.
  • a site user can still re-sort the items according to their preferences, but always have a quick way to restore the "default" ordering that the instructor has established.

column1: [SAK-7953] Ad-Hoc Group Management
column6:
As with sectioning, the full implications are bigger than a single tool, but this place is as good as any.

Instructors need to be able to create ad-hoc groups and group spaces (group collaboration areas), and they need to be able to manage these within their course sites.

Use Cases:

  • An instructor or TA creates an ad-hoc group of a subset of site users. Following creation group membership can be adjusted.
  • Each group has their own collaboration space which includes the usual collaboration tools.
  • Since students may typically spend more time in a group space than a course space, the group site should not require navigation through the course site.
  • An instructor has an option to import groups from another site (i.e. groups may span multiple sites)
  • An instructor or TA wants to send emails/messages/announcements to specific groups, and not have to remember an email address for each group.
  • Assignments and the gradebook should be "group-aware" to the extent that group projects may be submitted for grading, and feedback may be received on either an individual or group basis.
column10: Ad-Hoc Group Management
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44:
This kind of functionality also rose to the top of the UC Berkeley requirements list. We haven't had a a chance to think it through at the use case level but Clay's list is a great start. For us the general idea is that Sakai support group work in the classroom. For this to be a useful tool it should be integrated across tools where it makes sense (e.g. after the group is created instructors can send an announcement to the group, create assignments for the group, a dropbox gets created for the group, etc.)

In addition, since instructor and students needs and goals are different for group work and section management, they will have different requirements and workflows. I'm adding this comment since there was previous talk in the community that these 2 were virtually the same...just differenly named types of groups.
column48: I would like to add to this the ability to create groups automatically in more flexible ways: for example by randomly assigning students to groups.
column52: Seems to be related to more flexible groups.

column1: [SAK-8084] Sakai installations need more flexibility in time format
column6:
Currently, Sakai applications display time in an AM/PM format. This convention is best known in the United States and Canada, and can be confusing to users who are accustomed to a 0-23 hour format. The time format needs to to be settable system-wide. Another possibility is to let it be set by user preferences, or via the locale setting in the user's browser.

Use Cases:

  • All of the users at an installation at a Portuguese university are used to the 24 hour clock. When installing Sakai, the adminstrators choose to default to Portuguese language conventions. Users who log in with a browser set to a European locale or left at the default will see times expressed as a 24-hour clock rather than an 12-hour clock.

Related Functional Requests and Bugs include:

SAK-3823 Closed
SAK-3829 Closed
SAK-3830 Closed
