column1: [SAK-3675] Change scores displayed in Samigo to 2 decimal places.
column6:
In Samigo scores are rounded to the tenth place while the GB allows scores to the hundredth place. This should be consistant throughout the application.

I'm bumping up the priority on this as I've run into a use case where this discrepancy is causing a pretty big problem between GB-Samigo. I know at first glace it can seem trivial, but when it comes to the calculation of grades, faculty are very picky.

I have a Samigo assessment that has 1 question with 3.33333333333 points and I want it in the GB. The GB has the points for this assignment set to 3.33. However, since the scores in samigo are rounded to the 10th place - students can only get a maximum score of 3.3. Even if every student got every question on this assessment correct, the class average would read 99%. The student would see 3.3 out of 3.33.
column10: Change scores displayed in Samigo to 2 decimal places.
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44: We all agreed that : The default display for grades is 2 decimal places. Thus 1 out of 3 is displayed as ".33"
column48: The key thing to keep in mind is that the database should store and calculate based on as much accuracy as posssible. Rounding should only be a display thing. This is the way that the gradebook works. Thanks! L

column1: [SAK-8060] be able to specify site quotas on a user, user type, or site basis
column6:
it should be possible to specify quotas to My Workspaces and Sites on a User Type, and Site Type basis using the admin
interface (something like working with realms).
column10: be able to specify site quotas on a user, user type, or site basis
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44:
Currently there is a loophole in the quota management capabilities, which is that if a user exceeds her quota in My Workspace, she can simply create another X personal project sites, each with it's own quota.

A per-user quota would close this loophole.
column48: This seems like a global issue.
column52:
This is the closest JIRA I could find for this.

While this JIRA has a broader requirement here is a patch that adds a new configuration option to allow separate workspace quota's from site quota's.

workspaceQuota@org.sakaiproject.content.api.ContentHostingService=102400

This will set a "My Workspace" quota of 100MB.

This patch also works with the option of manually adjusting a workspace.

Also the configuration information for this option is included for the Configuration Viewer.

This code was tested for sakai 2.5.
column56: It would be really helpful if this patch could be generalized for site type, i.e. set individual quotas for course, project and myworkspace site types.
column60: Agree with Stephen here. The patch looks good but it would be helpful if it could be made to work in a slightly more general way.
column64:
I have created a new patch that hopefully provides enough for everyone!

Here are the new quota's:

registeredQuota@org.sakaiproject.content.api.ContentHostingService=1048576
maintainQuota@org.sakaiproject.content.api.ContentHostingService=1048576
guestQuota@org.sakaiproject.content.api.ContentHostingService=1048576
courseQuota@org.sakaiproject.content.api.ContentHostingService=1048576
projectQuota@org.sakaiproject.content.api.ContentHostingService=1048576
portfolioQuota@org.sakaiproject.content.api.ContentHostingService=1048576

I was also thinking since most people use the current siteQuota property to set their quotas that removing this would not be desirable so I am thinking of repurposing this option to be an overide, so that people who are customed to using can continue to use it with the same results.

So that means I need something to disable the use of siteQuota and was thinking of using a negative integer?

siteQuota@org.sakaiproject.content.api.ContentHostingService=-1

Once this is set then you can use the new options to set the appropriate quota.

Before I attach it I would like to get some comments.
column132: Don't forget that one can create new site and user types (e.g., honorscourse, honorsuser) at will. You probably need to think about how to handle that possibility in general way in your patched code.
column143:
What Seth said is correct. I think this is a bit too hardcoded. A better approach would be something that allows arbitrary site types rather than simply hardcoding in about 8 setters into the service (especially in light of the JCR work with CHS). I would recode it so that it works more like this:

content.quota.count = 2
content.quota.1 = course:1048576
content.quota.2 = project:1048576

Or something like that.
Thoughts?
column150:
I agree. I was thinking of having something in the admin interface to manage quotas. That would avoid the hardcoding problems just mentioned. We could have a couple of default quotas (eg, myworkspace and site default quota values)

I'm not really sure about that, but isn't there a configuration file for each site type? could a quota be defined there? If a site needed a different quota, then it could be set as a variable in the site definition (as other variables are) via the admin interface.

As for user types couldn't the user templates be used? that way, the admin could override the default values.

If the admin interface is used, we can avoid changing properties files, and eventually restarts.
column154:
After gathering info from the dev list here is the implementation that seemed most accepted.

A property to configure site types quota should look like:

content.quota.

{sitetype}

=

{value in KB}

example:

content.quota.course=1048760
content.quota.project=1048760

Sets all course sites to 1GB.

If the user has not configured a site type it will default to the value from siteQuota@org.sakaiproject.content.api.ContentHostingService

You can still set a unique value for individual sites nothing has changed here.

Here at UVa, we've just stumbled across the same problem Jean-François reports above; content.quota appears to be being ignored in 2.9.1. Setting the value for site types works except for "My Workspace" sites.

I was able to get a global quota working as content.quota is supposed to by using siteQuota@org.sakaiproject.content.api.ContentHostingService (which I saw mentioned above). That's all we needed, so I haven't pursued specifying a my-workspace-specific quota.

[update] Aaron Zeckoski has opened SAK-23640 Closed to address this issue.

column1: [SAK-7888] Adminstrators should be able to block user login
column6:
Adminstrators should be able to disable a user's access to Sakai. Deleting a user's local record within Sakai isn't sufficient given the possibility of an external user directory provider being used to identify the user during login.

As originally described, this requirement might be met by simply blocking login attempts and giving the usual "invalid login" alert.

SAK-8014 Closed describes a similar requirement, except for user access to a particular site rather than to all of a Sakai installation. It includes the ability to give the "banned" user a message explaining what's happened, which might be useful here as well.

Use Cases:

  • An employee has been terminated but is still included in the local LDAP directory. Access to Sakai resources and applications must be immediately revoked.
  • A student appears to be using their local workspace to store and share illegal material. The student's access should be blocked pending an investigation.
column10: Adminstrators should be able to block user login
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

One reason I ask is the existence of SAK-8014 Closed , which specifies disabling user access on a site by site basis, and optionally displaying a message explaining the reason for blocking access. I'm wondering what use cases that wouldn't cover.

column1: [SAK-8122] Adminstratiors should be able to view a user's profile data
column6:
The personal data which is edited and displayed by the "Profile" tool is more extensive than the data which is edited and displayed by the "Users" tool. However, the only way to see "Profile" data for a user other than oneself is via the "Roster" tool on a particular site. Administrators have no way to access it. Since the Profile data is system-wide, there should be a system-wide way to see it.

(Behind the scenes, the "Users" and "Account" tools access legacy user data whereas the "Roster" and "Profile" tools access newer core services for EduPerson-style data.)

One way to approach this would be to add "Profile" links in the administrative "Users" tool. Another way would be to implement a replacement for the legacy "Users" tool which takes advantage of the newer data and provides more services.

Use Cases:

  • The system administrator sees that a user has been causing dozens of crashes over the past two days. There's no response from the user's email account. The admin goes to the user's profile to find their phone number, department, and possible IM information.

column1: [SAK-7812] Email notification sent when item is added to Drop Box
column6:
One should be able to "watch" Drop Boxes, both on a site basis and on an individual basis, such that when a document is uploaded, a notification email is sent.

Use Cases:

  • Instructor turns on notification for Drop Boxes in their course site, so that as students drop off items, they are notified, so they can start work on grading the items.
  • Instructor turns on notification for a specific student's Drop-Box, who they interested in giving feedback to as soon as the student submits.
  • In a project site, a team lead wants to be notified as soon as team members submit an item via drop-box so they can start work on it.

column1: [SAK-3674] Gradebook / Assessments not going to gradebook if name already existed
column6:
Here is the sequence of events which caused the assessment not to show in GB:

User created a user-defined assignment in GB called 'Quiz 1'
User removed assignment from GB (marked as removed=1 in DB)
User created assessment called 'Quiz 1' in Tests & Surveys.
Results failed to go to GB just because there was an existing gradable object named 'Quiz 1' even though this assignment was user-defined and not linked to the external app Tests & Surveys.

When GB checks to see if an existing assignment exists upon an external app import, it should check other fields like removed or external app or this problem will occur again.

column1: [SAK-7916] Email Archive should be deep-linkable/bookmarkable
column6:
It is currently impossible to "link" to a message, because the tool state is (apparently) in the session.

The use cases are myriad, but for example:

A student asks "what were the requirements for the robot-building contest?". Another student replies with a link to the message in the email archive where the professor states the requirements. Currently that is impossible.

Even I as a sakai implementor would love to be able to send a link to (or bookmark) various sakai-dev emails. Currently one cannot do that.

At the very least (although it is really not totally sufficient either) the email could be handled like resources are, we there are "canonical" urls to retrieve them. Although really, the link should place the user in the context of the site and mail archive tool not just deliver the text of the message. However, currently there is no way to do that in Sakai in general, so maybe this is even a bigger requirement!

I am marking this as "Essential immediately" because, really the email archive tool is only useful for casual browsing without it. And really, given the slowness of the archive, it is not really useful for that either.

column1: [SAK-7777] Email Preferences should be per worksite
column6:
Currently Email Preferences are set per sakai installation rather than per worksite. It is highly desirable to allow the user to set this per worksite (and will likely become essential when the number of worksites grows large enough).

E.g. Personally, on sakaiproject.org, I would like to receive individual email from the sakai-dev worksite, but digests from the other worksites.
In a collaborative setting, a given person may be involved in several different collaborations, but may only have an active daily interest in only one or two. Or perhaps one of his collaborations has become "too chatty", so he wants to only read it as a digest, but still wishes to receive the others as individual emails.

I think a good model would be one where an individual can set a "default" preference, but can override that default for any specific worksite.

I marked this as "critical within a year" because although locally we may not have that many collaborations at first (we will be in pilot) , as we go into production (4-6 mos.) for collaborations and as we introduce pilot courses (6-12 months) the need will quickly become critical as the number of worksites an individual is likely to be participating in grows.
column10: Email Preferences should be per worksite
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

column1: [SAK-3672] Over-quota message is misleading and uninformative
column6:
If you attempt to upload a file which would exceed the worksite or folder quota, you get an error:

Alert: Adding this resource would place this account over quota. To add this resource, some resources may need to be deleted.

1. It is erroneous to refer to "this account", as quotas are enforced per worksite or per folder, not per user.

2. The user is not informed as to what the quota is.

Suggested revision:

Alert: Adding this resource would exceed the quota allocated for this worksite or folder (XXX MB). To add this resource, some resources may need to be deleted.

Controlled in: content/content-bundles/resources/content.properties:overquota

column1: [SAK-8070] Redesign the resources tool to be more document and student centered
column6:
The resources tool, as it is right now is folder centred. This means I can categorise my documents in only one category. For instance if I make a folder for each course I'm in and one of my documents is essential for two or more courses I'll have to make a copy of the document for each folder it needs to be in. I would like Sakai to be document centred and to enable me to categorise/organise my documents in more than one way.

The resources tool is worksite centred. Sakai is about collaboration and collaboration in Sakai takes place in worksites. If I want to share my documents with other students and faculty the only way to do this is by starting or participating in a worksite. And I'll have to make a copy of the document for each worksite I want to publish it in. I would like Sakai to support ad hoc collaboration without the need to start a worksite and to enable me to share my documents without the need to copy them.

The OSP FX (functional requirements) group made a description of a resources tool that is more flexible and student centred, enabling collaboration in worksites and ad hoc collaboration. I would like this vision to be in the centre of Sakai. Mock-ups can be found at http://portfolios.itd.depaul.edu/ospi/Prototypes/OSPInterfacePrototypes.htm. Of special interest for this discussion are the links 'Manage a Collection' and 'Publish a portfolio'.

column1: [SAK-7912] Allow a user to disable email notifications
column6:
We would like a setting in the preferences tool that allows a user to specify that no mails should be sent from the sakai system to his/her mail account.

There should also be an option to turn off this control at an institutional level (probably controled through sakai.properties) and to override it at a site level.

Use Case:
Student A is tired of getting email, they turn off their notifications. They should receive a series of warnings before they are allowed to turn it off that indicate they may miss important announcements. It should also indicate that the site owner can override the setting.
Use Case 2:
The instructor wants to send out a notification about class being cancelled. He knows that some students have turned off their notifications. He should be able to override the flag and send a notification that will reach all students.
Use Case 3:
Institution B wants to force students to always get notifications in Sakai. They turn on the notification globally and the control disappears. All settings are maintained and if the global flag is turned off, the users who turned off notifications will not get new messages.
column10: Allow a user to disable email notifications
column19: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
column44: When this is implemented, please keep in mind that some institutions may want to turn off the ability to block emails entirely. The original reason block didn't apply to high priority notifications was to allow instructors to be sure that an email was redeived by all participants, and that they couldn't subsequently claim that they never received the email. So allowing an institution to prevent the 'block all emails' control from showing up in the UI, or maybe allowing site owners to control whether in their site users can block emails would be useful.
column48: It would be nice if the notifications could be turned off simply by clicking on a link in the footer of a recieved email rather than having to log back into Sakai to do it. A student may enroll in a course but then for whatever reason, stop attending after a few weeks. Sooner or later they forget their Sakai login but continue to recieve what to them is now spam. Having forgotten how to login to disable things, they're effectively condemned to recieve spam until the class ends. This isn't a hypothetical use case – it happened to me when I subscribed to a umich course but only visited it once at the beginning of the semester and then promptly forgot my umich login.

column132:
Use Case 4:
Support staff are enrolled in many courses but would prefer to NOT receive emails from all of the courses they are supporting. Result could closely match first use case.

To satisfy this use case, would it be possible to disable emails to a specific site role?
column143: MAINT TEAM REVIEW: This feature request is currently unassigned and will be reviewed. In line with stated Jira practice http://confluence.sakaiproject.org/display/MGT/Sakai+Jira+Guidelines Feature requests that are not going to be implemented will be closed with a status of "wont fix". If you intend implementing this issue please ensure that its up to date and assigned correctly
column150:
I'm working with the owner of several huge Med School sites who wants to be able to add guests who can look around and search the site for materials but they don't want these "special participants" to get spammed with site notifications intended for . It's not possible to adjust role permissions because the tool permissions aren't granular enough.

This functional lack has played out in other ways over the years; it's fairly common for support to get contacts from alumni complaining about getting site emails years after they've graduated. It can be difficult to track down which site(s) is the culprit and since we have a policy of not making changes to sites without the consent of the owner resolution can be problematic.

An argument can be made that this should almost be classified as a bug since it would seem to be a "no-brainer" function. The thinking in the early design was that we didn't want students being able to shut off important notifications but the "low notification" solution is pretty useless; every instructor thinks that what they are posting is important, otherwise they wouldn't bother. My personal experience is that users want notifications either Off or On. Why not an option in MWS to turn off all site notifications?

David

column1: [SAK-7844] Log Searching Tool
column6:
An admin tool that will allow admins to check the logs in order to know when a person took a quiz, accessed an area, and what they did when they accessed said area.

The search should be able to be limited by users, sites, and dates. For example, I want to search the logs for the last week for site "Test site A" and user "student B" with a search term "quiz 4".

Use Case:
A student claims to have taken an online quiz 2 weeks ago but they have no grade in the gradebook. The admin (helpdesk support person) needs to be able to search the logs (through the interface) to see if there are any indications that the student took the quiz but the data was lost or removed.

column1: [SAK-7786] Merge Course/Site Tool
column6:
An admin and instructor tool that will merge courses or sites into a target course, however, this tool is for instructors not admins. It would allow instructors to merge one course into another to allow teaching of several sections of courses within one sakai course.

The merge tool should do the following:

  • identify the course/site to be the target or repository of the course sections
  • identify or select the courses to be merged into the target course
  • merge the enrollments into the target course for all roles (stdts, instructors, GTAs, etc) and data updates will automatically take effect within the target course
  • this action (the merge) can be undone
  • still identify students which were enrolled in the pre-merge sites

Use case:
Instructor A is teaching 2 courses that meet on different days. He would like to post all course materials, tests, etc... on one worksite. He would like to also be able to send announcements to all students, or just students in the class that meets on the first day. At the end of the semester, he will split the site back into the 2 original sites and post final exam information. When the classes are split, the course materials and data should be duplicated in both classes.
column10: Merge Course/Site Tool

column1: [SAK-7928] Admin Copy Tool
column6:
An admin tool that will copy a course or a site for Faculty not Admins thus freeing up admins for this function. Faculty will still want to copy courses or sites even with the WebDav respository. The batch import/export tool does not allow instructors or site maintainers to target specific areas.

The copy tool for instructors should do the following:

  • identify the course/site to be copied
  • identify the target to be copied to (new course, existing course)
  • identify areas of the course to be copied allowing specific material or areas to be copied (includes assessments, images, etc.)
  • will be able to copy user data (optional) if desired

column1: [SAK-7768] Split up Functionality of site.upd Permssions
column6:
Finer grained permssions are needed on edit functions for site.upd. Currently it allows a user to add, remove, and mark active/inactive other useres in a site. It would be better, however, if you could grant the ability to mark a user active/inactive without the ability to remove them, as you don't want instructors accidently removing a user and their work from a site.

To be more specific and correct, it looks like this issue is asking to have site.upd permissions NOT include the ability to manipulate users. Some permission that only allows an instructor to change things about the site but not adjust the memberships or add/remove them. This is already the case. However, I think they probably also want the current permissions made even finer grained.
The current site update permissions are:
site.upd - change things about the site, general control over the site
site.upd.grp.mbrshp - add/edit/remove group memberships

column48:
From SAK-14205:

Configure permissions for roles to accommodate users who need to perform some subset of the activities that site.upd permits.

2.5 introduced site.upd.site.mbrshp and site.upd.grp.mbrshp permissions. Excellent. Can we take this a step further?

Here are some suggestions:

1. Create permissions for the following tools/activities so that managing these tools/activities doesn't depend on the site.upd permission.

site.upd.view.siteinfo
site.upd.permissions
site.upd.tools
site.upd.siteinfo
site.upd.access
site.upd.import
site.upd.duplicate
syllabus.manage
podcast.manage
forums.manage
postem.manage
webcontent.manage
news.manage
sections.manage

2. Remove site.upd from functions.require in tool reg file for Site info tool and change it to site.upd.view.siteinfo.

3. site.upd could still function as designed and override any absence of above listed permissions

4. currently site.upd.site.mbrshp and site.upd.grp.mbrshp are only effective if a role also has the site.upd permission. Would this issue be cleared up if item #2 were implemented?

Here's what I wrote on the dev list:

There's really (at least) 3 different permissions at work here:

1) Add/remove participants, change the membership of the course
2) Manage participant status (Active/Inactive)
3) Manage participant role (e.g., Student, TA, Instructor)

and I can imagine scenarios where you'd want to give instructors one (or two) but not the other(s). It looks like site.upd.site.mbrshp is still a little too broad if it encompasses all three of these permissions.

column1: [SAK-7809] Left-hand Menu Should be Permission Sensitive
column6:
In most tools the permissions can be set to specify what each role can do in a tool. In some cases, there can be roles for which a tool has no usefull purpose at all and doesn't even display anything. If a user cannot get anything out of a tool, then they should not see that tool in their left-hand menu.

The left-hand menu in a site lists the pages available. Since most sites generally configure each page with only one tool, page and tool are roughly equivalent in this requirement. If there is more than one tool on a page, then just the tool on the page needs to be hidden, and not the entire page hidden.

Use Cases:

  • An instructor could decide that students do not need access to:
    -osp.legacy.review
    -osp.presTemplate
column10: Left-hand Menu Should be Permission Sensitive
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44: Incoprorated additional information from SAK-8024 Closed .
column48:
I attached a patch for 2.1.1 and the already patched CharonPortal.java
What it does:
Fulfills the REQ relying on two configuration tags of the tool xml file:
Examples:
<configuration name="roles.allow" value="maintain,Instructor" />
and/or
<configuration name="roles.deny" value="access,guest" />

If no configuration is found access is granted. Although not necessary, both roles.allow and roles.deny could be specified (in this case, the order is allow,deny).
Page button is displayed if the page contains at least one tool for which the user has permission; it is not displayed if all tools on that page (usually one) are forbidden to that user.

I did this patch because we cannot wait until a formal solution is done and I shared to others unpatient users. I did not create specific tags in the tool xml file because it could not be backwards-compatible - it would require modyfications on at least on Interface (Tool) on which there can exist several class implementations .

Hope it helps in some way.
Nuno

column1: [SAK-8029] Site-Specific and Tool-Specific Notification Preferences
column6:
Currently the "Preferences" tool appears only once for each user, in that user's "My Workspace". Preferences for email notification of changes are set there and apply to all worksites.

Sakai should also support worksite-specific preferences which can override the default preferences.

This need will become critical as the number of worksites an individual is likely to be participating in grows.

Use Cases:

  • You want daily-digests to monitor emails from one extremely chatty site, but need instant individual emails from another in which you play a leadership role.
  • You've joined a site to hear about upcoming events. You want to receive Announcement notifications from that site, but not Resource or Email notifications.

column1: [SAK-7959] Instant Messaging
column6:
Instant Messaging support in Sakai is an oft requested feature. There are a variety of approaches suggested.

(1) Convert the Users Present List into a Buddy List for the site; or for the system, with users in the site you are currently in differentiated somehow from users in other sites in which you are a member. Clicking on a name starts a chat with that person; or enters the default chat room for the site.

(2) Integrate with existing IM clients.

(3) For sites not using "user presence" build an IM tool; very similar in that case to existing chat, but supporting private conversations too.

(4) When messages are sent in Chat display some sort of notification to other site participants who are logged in.

column189:
"Section awareness" brings user-interface overhead as well as programming work, and making section-filtering visible within an already complex tool may make it unusable.

For many tools, it might be more efficient to think of section awareness at the site management layer. Given a way to create a sub-site (a folder within a site), the site administrator or instructor might give only certain sections access to that sub-site. Or might give section-specific access to an individual page or tool; e.g., the "Lab 2 Wiki" tool instance. The framework could then handle authorization checks before passing requests through to the tool code, and the tool code (and tool UI) wouldn't have to change at all.

Confluence is a good example of how this might work. (Yes, I know that Confluence could be thought of as just a big, big wiki, but it's big enough to include its own administrative tools for subsite setup and user/group management.)

Yep, the original request was that links take you to the full view of the item inside that item's tool. The goal of sending the user to the item view in the tool is to place them in the appropriate context for interacting with the item. In the case of Announcements, most folks are only going to be able to read it, so there isn't much interaction left for them to do, other than navigate to the next announcement. Announcements is currently the only tool synopsis which currently contains links, so part of this requirement is also for all synopsis views to contain links.

column1: [SAK-8115] Sakai Saving State - Moving between tools and within pages of a tool should behave conistently for users.
column6:
User need a consistent model for what will happen when they "go someplace else" within Sakai.

Currently, when you move between tools sometimes the tool the user left remains in the same state so when the user returns, they are dropped in the middle of a tool. For other tools, the tool resets itself when a user leaves it so when the return to the tool they arrive at the main page.

There is similar inconsistency with navigating within a tool. Sometimes, moving away from a page (but staying within the tool) saves the users data on page (a form for instance) until they come back. And in other tools, if the user moves away from a page without saving, the data will not be saved and the next time they visit that page it will be refreshed.

Original requirement below before combining this one with another:

Currently Sakai saves the state of a tool when you navigate away from it. For instance, if you are part way through creating a Resource and you click on the Schedule, when you come back to Resources, you'll find yourself right where you left off creating a new Resource, which can lead to confusion if you do not want to resume the process, are looking to do something different in Resources now, and are not familiar with the reset button for tools. Another approach is to reset a tool, and not save its state, when you navigate away from it, which means when you come back, if you want to resume your process, then you've lost everything you've done up to that part and have to start over. (Some other aspects of Sakai's behavior, which may compound the problems experienced here, include lack of support for the browser's back button and the percieved expectation that clicking on a tool in the left-hand menu, when already viewing the tool, should reset the tool, as opposed to learning about the little reset-icon in the top-left of the tool.)

There has always been a lot of debate over which model to adopt. The choice of saving state or not should be a system-wide configuration option.
column10: Sakai Saving State - Moving between tools and within pages of a tool should behave conistently for users.

column1: [SAK-8165] Direct URL Access to a Resource Folder
column6:
Folders in Resources should be accessible by URL. (Note that folders provide a URL in their properties, however, it does not work.)

The URL would be useful in many scenarios, particularly when the folder in question is a public folder and you desire to send people straight to it. For instance, when sending an email, rather than pasting in the URLs to each item ( SAK-107 Closed ), one could use just a single folder's URL.

Note that Rutgers has modified Sakai to support this sort of direct URL access and directory display listing ( SAK-3442 Closed ).

column1: [SAK-8043] Easy editing of dates for dated materials
column6:
A couple use cases have surfaced as part of the various requests for this functionality (see linked issues for background):

  • Shift Site's Dated Material Forward for Re-Use in Future Semesters
  • Set or update dates for all of a tool's "objects" in one interface.

In order to re-use a site in future semesters, whether by editing it or duplicating it, one of the big tasks is updating all the timed-related content. For instance, while the content of Assignments may remain mostly unchanged from semester to semester, the timing of their delivery, due dates, closing, etc., is always going to be different. Another example would be events in Schedule which represent the course's meeting times, and perhaps contain links to the appropriate lecture notes for each particular time. It would be nice to have a way to bulk move such time-dependent content forward for a new semester. For instance, it would be nice to be able to specify a new "first day" for a course, and have all the Schedule events moved relative to the difference with the old firest day; taking into account, of course, the differences such as university-wide off-days defined in a system-wide calendar.

In fully online courses instructors like to set up all of their materials in advance of the start of the course and set dates during the semester for when assignments will open, are due and are retracted. Doing this for each assignment one at a time is not very efficient. If there was a single page where you could adjust dates for all assignments that would be a big time saver.
column10: Easy editing of dates for dated materials
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44: Can a feature like this be managed easily in practice? One challenge is that fall semesters often have less weeks than spring semesters. How would the algorithm accomodate this and how would it be presented to the end user? Would the algorthm account for this expansion or contraction in semester durations? Would it simply move every due date forward a specified number of days (accounting for semester specific holidays) or would it move it forward in proportion to the length of the semester?
column48:
Good questions. In our case, even though the total number of weeks varies between semesters, the actual number of class sessions generally stays the same. If there is one or two more or less class sessions, then it would still be nice just to move it all forward and then fine-tune the few sessions you need to in order to accommodate the differences.

As to an algorithm, one way would be for Sakai to be aware of when class sessions occur and to think of Schedule events not only in terms of when they occur temporally, but also which ordinal class session they are of the semester (1st, 2nd, 3rd, ...). So, when I create a course site, it would pre-populate the Schedule with appopriate events (e.g., Lecture, Discussion, Lab) based on when my course meets. I could then attach appropriate materials to each meeting, such as my PowerPoint slides for each lecture event. If I decide to cancel a regular scheduled class, such as the day right before a major vacation break, then I would delete that paricular event from the Schedule; or, if I need to stick in a make-up session, I could insert that into the Schedule. (And it would be real nice if I could then slide the remaining class sessions around, if needed, if I made the deletion or addition after the semester started.) The next time I teach the course then, I could choose to migrate that information forward, perhaps with a UI something like a table that lists out my class sessions from the previous semester in one columne and matches them up with the class sessions in the current semester. I could then go trough and delete or insert class sessions here and there, if necessary, to get things to copy over to the dates I want; and, if possible, drag-and-drop sessions to change to order, if I decide to teach differently But I deviate here into design, the goal is to make re-use and re-scheduling of past material to a new semester as easy as possible.

column1: [SAK-8008] Offline component for learners to study while not connected to the internet
column6:
One of the factors hindering the implementation of e-learning in Africa (and South Africa) is limited and expensive Internet connections. Low bandwidth remains an issue and prevents the delivery of rich media to learners. An alternative to increasing bandwidth to cater for this problem is the dissemination of learning content from a central server during off-peak hours. Internet connections can be used to keep learning content up to date on the remote computers. Because content can be downloaded once and studied without the need to remain on-line for extended periods costs can be greatly reduced for the learners. The learner can however still connect to the central server for learning activities such as discussion groups, reading of announcements etc.

What is needed is an intelligent off-line client that can update content from time to time as is needed. This client will provide the learner with most (all?) of the same functionalities as he/she will find on-line.
column10: Offline component for learners to study while not connected to the internet
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44: http://lancespeelmon.wordpress.com/2007/05/31/google-gears-enables-offline-web-applications/
column48:
Some useful observations on the scope of what off-line can mean from Peter Crowther's sakai-dev email:

----Original Message----
From: Peter Crowther Peter.Crowther@melandra.com
Sent: Thursday, May 31, 2007 11:18 AM
To: michael.feldstein@oracle.com; W.Y.Koopal@utwente.nl
Cc: sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org
Subject: RE: Offline use of Sakai?

> From: Michael Feldstein michael.feldstein@oracle.com
> This sounds very interesting. I'd love to hear some opinions
> regarding how hard it would be to do it.

Depends what you want to do.

Disconnected computing in the general case is fraught with problems,
ranging from the sheer size of the data you might want to take with you
to security issues. We wrestled with some of these on the Manchester
VPE/PLE project a couple of years ago. One telling example is where a
student wants to be able to take an assessment test offline. If it's
computer-marked and you want them to receive their mark, you're going to
have to release some kind of answers file onto their machine - a
non-starter for anything on which the student is assessed. Similarly,
merging database contents between a central online store and many
disconnected instances, some of which may have been away for an extended
period and where the central resource may have changed in the meantime,
is an "interesting" problem.

However, there are specific cases that are clearly much simpler, and
these are where the site needs to provide content and interaction that
is public and read-only. Assuming there's no desire to log users'
access to resources (or the institution is willing to live with
limitations in the logging), quite a lot of the practical use of a
system falls into this category. Here, the database facilities in the
Google offering look fascinating - I've played with using MSDE instances
in the past to take snapshots offline from a central database, and this
looks like it could provide a cross-platform way of doing the same
thing.

It's an interesting area, and one in which I'd love to do more work - if
I were a developer of independent means!

  • Peter

column1: [SAK-3654] Quickstart does not run successfully because it runs out of memory
column6:
Quickstart demo of 2.1.0 and it runs out of memory very quickly. So we need to update the Quickstart instructions.

The easiest way I have found to get the memory settings right is as follows.

Start->Control Panel->System->Advanced->Environment Variables

Make a variable named

JAVA_OPTS

Set it to be

-Xmx512m -Xms512m -XX:PermSize=16m -XX:MaxPermSize=128m -XX:NewSize=128m -XX:+UseConcMarkSweepGC -XX:+UseParNewGC

This is the same process as setting JAVA_HOME on Windows which is already part of QuickStart instructions.

We need to also update the instructions for Mac and Linux to set these as well:

JAVA_OPTS='-Xmx512m -Xms512m -XX:PermSize=16m -XX:MaxPermSize=128m -XX:NewSize=128m -XX:+UseConcMarkSweepGC -XX:+UseParNewGC' ; export JAVA_OPTS

Since we don't run out of the box anymore with the default memory settings, we need to get this in our docs for 2.1.1
column10: Quickstart does not run successfully because it runs out of memory
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44:
Setting the JAVA_OPTS environment variable globally will affect all Java processes, not just sakai. Anyone running an hsql server, an eclipse IDE, or anything else Java would all of a sudden need 512MB for each JVM. Granted, a person running the quickstart probably isn't running these kinds of development tools, but it would be presumptuous to assume that they don't run any other java processes.

Perhaps the best way to set JAVA_OPTS for Sakai's tomcat is in either the startup.bat or catalina.bat files, or whatever startup script is used to run the quickstart demo. Since we can control the files in the quickstart's tomcat, this has an added advantage of reducing the number of steps needed to run the demo.
column48:
I would not use these settings. They have a number of probelms from my perspective:

The heap it way too small. Anything under a gig is trouble.

I would set Permsize to one setting - 128m if needed (although that might be hight), and not have this range. Java seems to me much happier when it has one fixed setting, not a range, for memory management.

The ratio of new size to total heap, in this case being about 1/4, might be ok, but is very important for proper management and I don't know what the right value is yet.

I would not use the the parallel collectors in any sort of production, without further proof that they are any good. They have the problelm of potentially fragmenting memory; something I'm not willing to conceed to just for fewer service gaps due to memory management. They also may be more expensive, overall, than the default collelctors.

The "-server" options is recommend for our sort of application.

It is also a good idea to instrument the catalina.out logs with memory management collection messages, so the memory management can be studies.

I am in the process of testing various memory management settings in a large load environment, but do not have recommentations yet.

I use this for a generic Sakai run:

-server -Xms1g -Xmx1g -XX:NewRatio=2 -verbose:gc -XX:+PrintGCDetails -XX:+PrintGCTimeStamps -XX:PermSize=128m -XX:MaxPermSize=128m

The ratio (2:1) of Tenured to Heap (Heap being 1/3 Tenured) is probably not optimal. Total memory footprint is probably about 1.5 gigs, although there's a HUGE stack (8 megs per thread, I believe, and we run with up near 200 threads), and I'm not quite sure where that is.

Folks running a 64 bit memory environment will probably have different optional settings (and memory setting options) than folks running a 32 bit. I'm currently in the 32 bit camp, btw.
column52:
I'd agree with Josh that it would be best from the end-user's perspective not to make this a documentation issue. The one question there is - can a developer commit to having this done in the next day or two before release? If that answer is "yes," someone please tell me right away.

If the answer is "no," (or if there's no answer) then I'll add an extra step to the docs.

I think some of Glenn's remarks about settings are based on hosting multiple users on a server. I don't believe that's the target audience of the demo. I know I've heard Mark and Chuck in the past talk about how Sakai can run on a developer's laptop just fine. I myself haven't had any testing issues with a 512mb heap.

I'll however use Glenn's set as a basis, and keep the heap low enough that people can still try it out on a middle-class laptop (which, again, I've been doing for QA deployment testing). Since it's the heap size and the permanent generation settings that are the real blockers for tire-kicking purposes, I'll leave out extra performance-tuning details. Although I'd like to trim down the arguments to an absolute minimum (the longer and more abstruse this is, the less it feels like a quickstart) I think Glenn's right that the GC messages should stay.

-server -Xms512m -Xmx512m -verbose:gc -XX:+PrintGCDetails -XX:+PrintGCTimeStamps -XX:PermSize=128m -XX:MaxPermSize=128m

column1: [SAK-3652] Misleading access option when creating a folder inside a publicly shared folder
column6:
If you create a subfolder inside a public folder (i.e. a folder whose access has been set to allow public view), then the public view access is inherited, and so the contents of the subfolder are also publicly accessible.

This is correctly displayed when you view the properties of the created subfolder, but at the time of creation, the access prompt reads:

Access Display to non-members (publicly viewable)

with the checkbox clear by default. This could lead a user (unaware that access is inherited and cannot be denied lower down) to believe that because she did not tick the checkbox, that folder would not be publicly accessible.

When permissions are implemented such that it's possible to deny inherited permissions, then that selector should have a 3-way state, i.e. inherit default, explicit grant, explicit deny.

Until such time, the checkbox should be removed, and it should display "Set to yes in a containing folder" in the same way as subsequent view/revise properties operations do.

column48:
Hi Jon,

Thanks, your patch is working. I tested against sakai_2.2.x revision 18370.
I did a small adjustment to the tab.jsp page and added some extra JSF tags to deal with conversion and validation. JSF has standard support for this kind of stuff so we can just as well use it...
That way you can leave out the String tabCountIn property and its getters and setters from UserPrefsTool.java. Just int tabCount and methods getTabCount() setTabCount() will do.

Only a few extra lines in tabs.jsp are needed:

<h:inputText value="#

{UserPrefsTool.tabCount}

" size="3">
<f:converter converterId="javax.faces.Integer"/>
<f:validateLongRange maximum="99" minimum="1"/>
</h:inputText>

Note the managed property is tabCount instead of tabCountIn.

<f:converter converterId="javax.faces.Integer"/> =>
For conversion between String and java.lang.Integer (and int primitive) values

<f:validateLongRange maximum="99" minimum="1"/> => Specify a range from 1 to 99, negative values are not allowed

When validation and conversion occur, it's complaining about a missing resource bundle defined in faces-config.xml: org.sakaiproject.tool.preferences.bundle.Messages.
This file doesn't exist, just add an empty Messages.properties and you're fine.

Bye, Tom

column1: [SAK-8167] Join Site by Requesting Membership
column6:
Add the additional option for sites to be joinable only by request. In otherwords, a user could browse the list of joinable sites, but instead of being able to join immediately, they would have to go through some soft of approval process. For instance, they could click on a link next to a site in the Membership tool that would provide them with a little form to fill out, whichi would then generate an email to the site owner(s), who could then click on a link in the email to accept or deny the join request (and maybe add a comment to the automate message and instructions), which in turn would generate an appropriate email back to the requestor.

Use Cases:

  • A project site where you don't know right away who all will be joining the site, but you don't want it to be wide-open for anyone to join. Receiving a request to join from someone would be a good enough threshold for them to have to cross to get in.
  • A site might have some pre-requisite for joining that can be validated through the join request.
  • A site you want to control access to, but not have to rely on Sakai administrators or out-of-band email requests to handle.
column10: Join Site by Requesting Membership
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44: Reviewed by "Worksite & Admin Tools"
column48: We have been thinking of implementing something like this at Yale for some time. So this Jira doesn't get lost, can someone update it so it includes versions 2.4.x and 2.5?
column52: Affects Versions updated per Cheryl's request.

If you intend implementing this issue please ensure that its up to date and assigned correctly

column132: CLE team bulk inactive issues cleanup - if this is important then reopen or create a new issue

column1: [SAK-7950] Option to Enforce Unique Site Titles
column6:
It would be nice to have support for enforcing unique site titles, currently Sakai allows one to have multiple sites with the same title, which can lead to confusion. (There are Sakai installations that are interested in multiple sites with the same title, so this could be implemented as an option.)

Use Cases:

  • Instructors often teach the same course over and over. If their course site doesn't have a title with temporal information, such as GS-440 versus GS-440-F06, then it becomes confusing as to which site is which after a couple semesters of teaching the same course. (Instructors don't necessarily always want to delete old sites either, as it may have material from students they wish to reference, or their university may require that keep old student material on-hand for a certain time period.)
  • Members of ad-hoc groups, such as project sites, which aren't uniquely named can also be confused as to which site is which. For instance, someone might be end up in multiple "Study Group" or "Lab Group" sites.
  • Folks searching for sites on the Gateway or trying to join sites in the Membership tool also have problems telling which site is which when the name is the same. (Some help is provided if the Term field is used in the Gateway for course sites but not project sites, and in the Membership tool the Description is displayed, but only if it is simple text.)
column10: Option to Enforce Unique Site Titles
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44:
From SAK-7966 Closed by Chris Brandt:

Once you have several years worth of terms for old course worksites, it will be difficult to determine which is the appropriate one to join from the memebership tool unless the term and year are part of the site label.

Adding a colum to the display of Joinable worksites which shows the term (if applicable) would be a valuable addition.

This wouldn't necessarily be usable by insitutions that have completely closed courses, but those with OCW initiatives such as MIT, or those who allow all site members access to all sites (such as UCD SVM) would benefit.
column48: Reviewed by Worksite & Admin Tools.

column1: [SAK-8093] Email Confirmation When Submitting High-Risk Items
column6: Send a confirmation email when Sakai has successfully received a high-risk item. For instance, when a student submits an Assignment, they should get an email receipt that the system completed the process. The email can include an appropriate reference ID and time-stamps. This option could be configured to be system-wide, by site, or by student; a good default would be to have it on system-wide.

Kim,
I think that was how it was designed - that the preview page wasn't an edit page, but just a way to show how the thing looks before submitting it. If you want to make a change, you have to click revise to get back to the edit page.

thanks
John

column1: [SAK-7918] Import/Export/Synchronize Schedule Data with outside calendars
column6:
Support for the ability to import/export/synchronize schedule data with external applications, or to integrate in general an exisiting enterprise calendar system for use with Sakai. Many schools already have an enterprise calendar system that users are working with outside of Sakai and would a like a way to exchange data between the two so they can have their schedule in "one place". Many users also have PDAs or cell phones with scheduling programs they would like to be able to view all their scheduling data in.

Some external scheduling applications also have web interfaces, which could be placed in a Sakai Web Content tool; however, that doesn't achieve any direct integration, such as creating an Assignment whose open date would be posted to the external scheduling software.

From SAK-7783: Schedule tool needs to be enhanced to allow exporting to common formats.
It needs to allow syncing with other calendars as well, so that importing calendar from another tool a 2nd time doesn't add duplicate events.
column10: Import/Export/Synchronize Schedule Data with outside calendars
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44: We, at University of Lleida (Spain), are begining to work in this requirement, using caldav (http://ietf.webdav.org/caldav/home.html) in a brand new calendar tool.
column48: It seems like this feature is not available in 2.4 as well. Are there any plans to make this feature available in 2.5?
column52: A good portion of the functionality described here has been added to Sakai for 2.5. See SAK-191 Closed for details on iCal export support and SAK-7342 Closed for details on iCal import/subscription.
column56:
This issue was originally a Feature Request from the Sakai 2.2-era. Sakai's calenadar features have evolvoed substantially since this issue was created and functionality that addresses some of the concerns raised here has been added, (e.g., SAK-191 Closed , SAK-7342 Closed ), and to reflect that, this issue is being Resolved for Sakai 2.5.

If there is additional functionality that is still desired, please detail it in a new Feature Request relative to the capabilities of Sakai 2.5.

column1: [SAK-3645] TAs are listed in "Assignment List by Student"
column6:
When I view "Assignment List by Student" I see all student users but I also see all TA users. It seems odd that TAs would also submit assignments. Either TAs are not suppossed to be in this listing or the view name should be changed to something like "Assignment List by User".

To replicate:
"(Instructor) Click Assignment List and View Assignment List by Student
Click triangle to expand list of assignments available for each student"
column10: TAs are listed in "Assignment List by Student"
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44: TAs shouldn't be able to submit assignments in the courses they are instructing by default.
column48:
TAs were given the ability to submit, like instructors, because of original requirements to allow them to submit in order to test the submission process. Whether or not someone shows up on the list of students is controlled by whether they have the 'new' permission, the logic being that if they can create assignments, they aren't going to have submissions that would be graded.

So if a TA role has submit (which it does by default) and doesn't have new (which it doesn't be default) then they will show up in the list by student.

Maybe a better way would be to tie it to grade, so that if a role had grade (but also had submit) those with that role woldn't show up in the list.
column52: "Test the submission process" seems like an edge case, which shouldn't be supported, if it is messing up the expectations of how the tool works.
column56: Well, it was put in ther e in the first place because of instructors wanting it. Taking it out would mess up how the tool works for them.
column60: The results of the poll on "DG: Assessment Tools" were 5 to 1 in favour of changing the out-of-the-box defaults so that TAs are not able to submit assignments, therefore also removing them from this list, potential problems with their grade being averaged in with students in gradebook, etc.
column64: We need to provide a way for instructors to submit as student yet keep them out of the grade lists and download zip files. Currently, the 'submit' permission doesn't fully control the submit ability - those with new can also submit so maybe it is a matter of making the submit permission the only control on submit ability.
column132:
With r34752, the OOTB ta role is created with asn.submit permission, hence ta users won't be included in the Assignment List by Student view, downloaded spreadsheet, download all zip file, or other grading view.

  • Zhen
column143:
I meant to say that the OOTB ta role is created WITHOUT the asn.submit permission.

Thanks,

column1: [SAK-8036] Emails Should Contain Site URL and Item URL
column6: When an email is sent from a site (e.g., an auotmated message, and email forwarded by tool Email Archive tool) it should contain the URL for the Site and the direct URL for the item the message references (e.g., an email in Email Archive, an announcement, a resource). This will enable the recipient to either easily access the site and some work the message reminded them of or to directly access the item in the context of the site and start their work from there.

column1: [SAK-7924] View Site as if in a Different Role
column6:
The ability for a user to view the site as it would be viewed by a user with a different role in the site. For example, an instructor being able to view a site as their students see it.

This is similar to, but not the same as the SUTool, which allows admin users to view the site as a specific user would see it.

column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44:
Another use case from a Resources discussion:

An instructor wants to demo their site in class as if they were a student looking at things.

"Our instructors often want to demo their site to students live in class. They don't want hidden materials in the default view of the Resource list, even for them. A way to hide this column from the list view, even just during the session if not as a "Hide availability in list view" Option, would help. I can't imagine being an instructor on Day 1, standing up in front of class to show students what the resource area looks like with three available resources and 30 marked hidden!"

column60: Greg, is there a design or spec that you could post here to describe this new feature and give folks an idea of how it works? Thanks.
column64: View of before a user selects a role. All roles available in the site (except the user's current role) are displayed in the dropdown.
column132: View of the page after a different role has been selected.
column143:
A new permission, "site.roleswap", is set for particular roles in any given site. The permission will determine if the role swapping capability is to display on the site.

Assuming the permission is set for the user's role for a site, a drop down menu with all the roles available in the site (except the user's current role) will display in the upper right. The user simply picks which role they wish to switch to. The user will be taken right back to the tool/page they were in with an updated display of what the page looks like to the role selected. This state will remain for other tools in the site, as well. There will be a hyperlink saying "Exit Role Swap View" where the drop down menu was prior. The user clicks on the link to return to their normal role and the page display will return to what it should normally be for the user. Should be noted that since the variable is unique, the state will not cross over to other sites a user may be part of.

In the background, after a user selects a different role, a unique variable is set in the session that will be checked on frequently in the authz tool, especially the "isAllowed()" functions. If this variable is found in authz, a different query is ran against the database to make sure the permission is exists in a site and return the appropriate true/false answer on the function. When the user exits the role swap view, logs out, or closes the browser, the session variable is deleted and will be back to a normal state.

column154: authz - r41665
column158:
Update on this:

The roles that can be switched to with this tool are now defined in sakai.properties so institutions can set them to whatever they want them to be (e.g. studentview.roles=Student,access ). This is not to be confused with roles that have permission to use the role switching mechanism. The UI will know if there's multiple roles for the site and will display a dropdown for the user to select which role to switch to or if its only 1 role, it'll be a standard anchor link.

Because of that change, that also makes the security a bit tighter and various checks are made throughout the code for sanity purposes. This helps ensure the system gets legit requests that an institution wants to allow.

Additionally, the caching is much more efficient now in the authz tool, so it should increase performance.
column167:
Attached 2 patch files, 1 for the kernel part for 2.6 and the other for the rest of the code.

Also attached the change to put in sakai.properties as well as the backfill sql.

Note on the backfill that you'll need to edit it first depending if you're doing mysql or oracle.
column171:
Some comments.

The Kernel Patch is Ok.

Can you confirm that there is an audit event when an a role is switched.

Where is a UI to switch roles ?

Is it on or off by default ?
column181:
I guess it isn't clear in the comments, so I'll try to clarify it better.

1. Run the SQL script (edit it first to uncomment and pick for mysql or oracle). The site.roleswap permission is given to Instructor for course and project sites by default.
2. Edit your sakai.properties and add in the content from the attached file (sak-7924-sakaiproperties.txt). Defaults are set to Student, Teaching Assistant, and access.
3. Apply both patches to your instance.

If those all all done, you should be good to go.

It is on by default. If the user has the site.roleswap permission and a role from the sakai.properties is found in the site, then something (link or dropdown) will render in the UI in the upper-right part of the screen. I guess you can easily turn this feature off on the site just by simply not having anything defined in the sakai.properties or having nothing with the site.roleswap permission.

From the UI and assuming you have the permission, there will either be a link that says "Enter (role name) view" or a dropdown with "View Site as: (dropdown with available roles)". After clicking the link or picking something from the drop down, the link will say "Exit (role name) view". Additionally, the tool that you are in will be reloaded onto the 'home page' of that tool and refreshed into whatever role you picked. You'll stay in this role throughout the site until you either logoff or click the exit link.

This event is tracked through variables in the session (which can be viewed in the portal section of the code). Its the key for triggering permission checks to check as a different role for what the user should be. This ensures the "swapped state" is only for a particular site for the user and can easily expire just from closing the browser and preventing any sort of weirdness the next time the user logs in.

Hopefully this will make it more clear. Feel free to edit the various roles to try out different combinations. Its suppose to be flexible in that regard.

column1: [SAK-7858] Case Sensitivity of Sorting
column6:
Sakai currently uses a case-senstive sort for lists, which is typical of ASCII sorting rules; upper-case letters sort higher than lower-case. Sorting could also be done on a case-insenstive basis. This should most be an option for installations to choose from, but probably needs to be enforced globally across the installation for all sorting for consitency of user-experience.

In terms of default, case-insenstive would be the prefered option. In training classes, people can't tell why sites sort as they do in Sakai now. Standard users don't think in terms of ASCII, nor would they order a stack of 3x5 cards this way.

Use Cases:

  • Sites might be named "ePortfolio Working Group" or "iPod Study", because that's the common and accepted capitalization of those special words, and people browsing for those sites would expect them to be with all the rest of the E's and I's, rather than finding them separately in the e's and i's from the rest of the e/E and i/I sites.
  • Instructors may require students to create project sites with standardized site names. Capitalization shouldn't determine where these show up in someone's list of sites, such as "econ 101 group project" versus "ECON 101 GROUP PROJECT".
column10: Case Sensitivity of Sorting
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44: What is the use case for this? Would there be a global option to switch the sorting to case-insensitive? Not a new tool, removed from "New Tool" component
column48:
Possible use cases:

Project coordinators might "ePortfolio Working Group" or "iPod Study" because that's the common and accepted capitalization. People browsing a list of available sites would expect these under E and I, not "e" and "i" after Z.

Instructors may require students to create project sites with a standardized site name. Capitalization shouldn't determine where these show up in someone's list of sites. Is there really a significant difference between these...?

econ 101 group project
and
ECON 101 GROUP PROJECT

In training classes, people can't tell me why sites sort as they do. Standard users don't think in terms of ASCII, nor would they order a stack of 3x5 cards this way.

column1: [SAK-8083] Support for directly entering images and rich text in "Worksite Information"
column6:
Site owners often want to include a richer description of their course or project besides just text, including images. While one could currently do this by creating an HTML document outside of Sakai or in the site's Resources, and then using the URL, it would be better practice to be able to create and edit such a rich Worksite Information page directly in the tool itself, and when editing or creating the Descirption initially in Site Info or Worksite Setup.

Use Cases:

  • Site owners would like to create and edit "Worksite Information" that includes rich text and images.

----------------------------
Original Description:

Faculty at UC Berkeley would like to be able to add images and rich text to the descriptions of their sites. Many consider the ability to place image(s) on the HOME page an important feature that is currently missing from bSpace. They would like to be able to better personalize their sites with image(s) that represent their classes/subject matter.
column10: Support for directly entering images and rich text in "Worksite Information"
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column44: Jeff, currently a user can place such content on the Home page by adding it to the "Worksite Information" part, though in a rather convoluted manner; they can create an HTML page in Resources (or even outside Sakai for that matter) and enter its URL in Worksite Information's options. So, picking up on your "better personalize" phrasing, how were do we need to improve upon this existing functionality? Would the requirement be satisfied by adding the option to the existing "Worksite Information" for directly creating richer content using the WYSIWYG editor, or is there more to this than that?
column48:
Peter,

Faculty members I've talked to don't need anything too fancy: Just the ability to add a single image to Worksite Information (an image which they feel represents the class), and edit the text with the Rich Text options found elsewhere in Sakai tools.

As far as implementation of this, I see it as simply a button labeled "Add image" and a text box with Rich Text options.
column52: For reference, attached is a screenshot of an example use case of what one might be trying to do. (In this case I created an HTML page with images on a separate web server and put the URL into Worksite Information. It would've been nicer and easier, however, to just create it by editing the options for Worksite Information.)
column56: Yes, this is the use I had in mind. However, so that faculty would not have to even consider layout, I was thinking it would be easiest just to have an image above and text below. For a class on Mayan art, for example, there would be an image of a Mayan sculpture and below it, the descriptive text for the course.
column60: Okay, so the key is as easy as possible Check out the WYSIWYG editor in Sakai's Tests & Quizzes (Samigo) tool, which let's you insert images; you don't need to worry about the layout unless you want to. If that's too complex of a solution to this, however, then perhaps the option should be to support uploading a single image and typing some text in a field that would appear below the image. Either way, it sounds like using the Worksite Information potion of the page is okay.
column64: Yes! The WYSIWYG editor in Tests & Quizzes looks perfect! However, when I tried inserting an image, it looked like the only option was to provide a URL. I think it would be necessary to be able to BROWSE for the image as well.
column132: At Portland State University, this issue is moving beyond simply adding images to the homepage. Several faculty members want an icon-bank similar to WebCT, and with that, the ability to post icons on the homepage. I have never been a big fan, and I'm unaware of a correlation between learning and icons and or images on the homepage. However, some of these requests are coming from users with special needs - specifically those with limited vision. They like a large image that directs them to the discussion board, chat, gradebook, etc. So, I am beginning to rethink the way I feel about this issue.
column143: Vincent, the functionality you describe sounds interesting, but distinct from the focus of Jeff's requirement. You should create a separate requirement for it, if it is functionality you are intereseted in seeing in Sakai.

column1: [SAK-3640] Mac WebDAV uploads fail when Sakai is configured for filesystem content storage
column6:
WebDAV uploads from Mac computers fail with 2.1.x installations as soon as they have been configured to use filesystem-based content storage.

Specific failures include:
Using Finder in OS X 10.4.4:
copy directory containing files >> gave error, but created empty directory
copy file >> gave error, file not uploaded

Using Goliath 1.0.1:
copy directory containing files >> gave error, but created empty directory
copy file >> gave error, created empty directory with the file's name

There is no corresponding failure for Windows-based WebDAV uploads.

If one reconfigures to return to DB-based content storage, the WebDAV problem again vanishes.

    cal/filestorage-2-1-1/

column60: Added WebDAV as a component as it plays a role in this...
column64: Golaith has had long-standing issues
column132:
Possible fix for Goliath users. Patches attached above.

Date: Fri, 27 Jan 2006 18:24:25 -0500 (EST)
From: Seth Theriault <slt@columbia.edu>
To: Clay Fenlason <clayf@bu.edu>
Cc: sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org
Subject: Re: WebDav and Sakai (Mac problems)

Clay Fenlason wrote:

> I've opened a Jira item on this, now that we have at least a clear
> breaking point:

I may have found a partial solution for Goliath's bad behavior when
copying a folder from the local drive into a Sakai site. I have been
working against Clay's 2.1.1_003 dev box.

After turning on massive debugging and comparing Goliath's logs for
connections to Sakai and a Xythos server, I noticed that Sakai was not
sending a "201 Created" response to Goliath's "MKCOL" request while
creating the new directory. Instead, Sakai was returning a "200 OK"
and Goliath was barfing. Now, I did some poking around the Web and
came across this Microsoft page that describes what how an "MKCOL"
transaction is supposed to go:

http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/default.asp?url=/library/en-us/e2k3/e2k3/_webdav_mkcol.asp

(Yes, I realize this is Microsoft document and that it may be less
than authoritative)

Pawing through DavServlet.java, I noticed the following at the end of
the end of doMkcol():

[...]
catch (InconsistentException e)

{ Log.warn("sakai","SAKAIDavServlet.doMkcol() InconsistentException:" + e.getMessage()); resp.sendError(SakaidavStatus.SC_FORBIDDEN); return; } // Removing any lock-null resource which would be present lockNullResources.remove(path); }

and compared it to the end of doPut():

[...]
catch (ServerOverloadException e)

{ Log.warn("sakai","SAKAIDavServlet.doPut() ServerOverloadException:" + e.getMessage()); resp.setStatus(SakaidavStatus.SC_SERVICE_UNAVAILABLE); return; } resp.setStatus(HttpServletResponse.SC_CREATED); // Removing any lock-null resource which would be present lockNullResources.remove(path); }

After a "PUT", Sakai is sending "201 Created" so I decided to mimic
it. Attached to this message are patches that add:

// send a "201 Created" not "200 OK"
resp.setStatus(HttpServletResponse.SC_CREATED);

to the end of doMkcol(). They are for TRUNK (r5554) and 2-1-1_003
(r4685) respectively.

Let's see how that works.

Seth
column143: Upping the priority on this
column150:
This was fixed in two modifications.

r5776 - applies Seth's patch so MKCOL returns the right status.

r5777 - fixes the underlying problem in ContentHosting which treated zero length blobs differently than the database.

In DB storage (for a long time now) - it is non-fatal to try to store
a zero length content body - the row is never added but there is no
error condition. In DB storage when reading when there was no body,
it was non-fatal and either a null stream was returned or an empty byte array.

Because of some new error checking code added to the storing of blobs in
the file system, ContentHosting reports ServerOverload in the case where there is
an attempt to store a zero length blob.

This modification changes the storage of a zero length blob in the file
system to be non-fatal. No file is created (paralleling how the DB works).
Code was added to the blob retrieval code to check for all of the cases
where the blob did not exist. However if the resource's metadata
indicates that a file has length > 0 and there is not data to read
(i.e. the file is gone) it is logged.
column154: My Hypothesis is that DAVFS does a bunch of zero-length file stuff that other clients do not.
column158:
We've applied this fix successfully to a 2.1.x development machine that mimics our production environment, and we did so merely by replacing the two affected files and doing a new build on the legacy project alone.

The development machine was doing SSL through Apache and mod_jk, connected to a restore of our
production Oracle DB and authenticating against the AD. Tested against Goliath and the native 10.4 client, as well as doing regression tests with Windows XP clients.

Since there are a number of clients and configurations that probably need vetting here, I won't close the issue yet. But we do consider it QA verified against the range of local configuration details we deal with.

column1: [SAK-3639] Old attachments are lost when student clicks "Add/Drop Attachments" to returned assignment.
column6:
Student attempts to add additional attachments to a returned assignment for re-submission. After clicking "Add/Drop Attachments" all of the original attachments are gone (except for URL attachments).

To reproduce:

1. Create an assignment that allows for attachments
2. Log in as student to submit the assignment. Add a PDF, DOC, XLS
3. Log in as instructor to grade the assignment. Return to student.
4. Log in as student to re-submit the assignment and click 'Add/Drop Attachments'

In the Resources view, all of the attachments are now gone. It would seem to me that the student should have a link to Remove the files.

NOTE: When only adding URL's, they seem to stay when clicking "Add/Drop Attachments".
